KRI, Kovats retention index. Feeding experiments were carried out in the MS liquid medium supplemented with 1% sucrose (total 15 days of incubation). Our feeding experiments showed a minor role of the MVA pathway in ent-kaurene synthesis. To examine how this minor incorporation affects plant growth, we analyzed the effect of exogenous MVL on the phenotype ofcla1−1 seedlings. Fig. 2 C shows thatcla1−1 seedlings accumulate green-yellow pigments in the presence of 1–3 mm MVL. However, the cla1−1albino phenotype was not fully rescued even at higher doses of MVL (data not shown). These results support our conclusion that the MVA pathway plays a minor role in the isoprenoid biosynthesis in plastids, where the major route is the MEP pathway. Likewise, we treated wild-type seedlings with varying concentrations of DX in the presence of mevastatin. Exogenous DX at 0.5 and 1 mm partially rescued the growth defect caused by mevastatin (Fig. 2 D). However, the growth inhibition was not completely restored even at higher concentrations of DX in the media. These results are consistent with our GC-MS data showing that the MEP pathway can partially contribute to cytosolic sterol biosynthesis. Using feeding experiments with [2-13C]DX or [2-13C]MVL, we showed that either precursor can be incorporated into bothent-kaurene and campesterol with different efficiencies. These experiments were carried out at concentrations of exogenous [2-13C]DX or [2-13C]MVL that were sufficient to overcome the effect of the cla1−1 mutation or mevastatin, respectively, nearly completely. To investigate the mechanism for crossover between MEP and MVA pathways, we determined the incorporation of labeled precursors when the metabolic flux through one of the pathways is limited. This set of experiments was carried out in liquid culture containing 1% sucrose. The cla1−1 albino phenotype was rescued only partially by 0.2 and 0.4 mm DX (Fig. 2 A). This suggests that DX is still limiting, and therefore, the MEP pathway is not saturated. Under these conditions, [2-13C]DX was still incorporated into campesterol, although the incorporation was lower (3 and 4% at 0.2 and 0.4 mm, respectively; Table III) than that obtained with the higher concentration of [2-13C]DX (7%). Similarly, [2-13C]MVL was incorporated intoent-kaurene (8%; Table III) when mevastatin-treated plants were fed with 1 mm MVL, which did not fully rescue the growth inhibition by mevastatin (Fig. 2 B). These results indicate that the incorporation of [2-13C]MVL intoent-kaurene and that of [2-13C]DX into campesterol occurs even when the MVA and MEP pathways, respectively, are limiting. Our data also showed that the concentrations of13C-labeled precursors in the media can modulate the amount of 13C incorporation into the products, which is evident by the decreased incorporation of [2-13C]DX intoent-kaurene at 0.2 mm [2-13C]DX (68%) relative to that observed at 0.8 mm[2-13C]DX (87%) (Table III). Our feeding experiments using 13C-labeled precursors have demonstrated that both MEP and MVA pathways can supply precursors for the biosynthesis of GAs in Arabidopsis seedlings. This study provides the first evidence that GAs can be synthesized through the MEP pathway. Because GAs and their precursor ent-kaurene are present at extremely low levels in plant tissues, we needed a sensitive method to monitor the incorporation of isotopically labeled intermediates. The use of mevastatin and the cla1−1mutation to block individual isoprenoid pathways allowed us to label metabolites efficiently. In stevioside biosynthesis in S. rebaudiana, feeding experiments with [1-13C]glucose and NMR were used to show that the diterpene moiety (a derivative ofent-kaurenoic acid) is synthesized through the MEP pathway. A contribution from the MVA pathway was not evident in this study. The inconsistency between this study and ours may be because of differences in plant species, tissue, or development stage, roles of the products (secondary metabolite versus growth regulator), or the inability to detect minor 13C incorporation by NMR. Because glucose can be incorporated into both the MEP and MVA pathways,13C-labeled glucose has often been used to label isoprenoids in vivo (38Adam K.P. Zapp J. Phytochemistry. 1998; 48: 953-959Google Scholar, 39Hirai N. Yoshida R. Todoroki Y. Ohigashi H. Biosci. Biotechnol. Biochem. 2000; 64: 1448-1458Google Scholar). However, it is not known whether exogenously applied 13C-glucose is equally distributed to the two pathways. This would be a crucial question when both MEP and MVA pathways are involved in the biosynthesis of target compounds. Crossover between the MEP and MVA pathways has been demonstrated in the biosynthesis of several terpenoids in other plant species using isotopically labeled DX or MVL (2Rohmer M. Nat. Prod. Rep. 1999; 16: 565-574Google Scholar, 40Schwender J. Gemünden C. Lichtenthaler H.K. Planta. 2001; 212: 416-423Google Scholar, 41Arigoni D. Sagner S. Latzel C. Eisenreich W. Bacher A. Zenk M.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 10600-10605Google Scholar, 42Piel J. Donath J. Bandemer K. Boland W. Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 1998; 37: 2478-2481Google Scholar). However, in all cases, cellular concentrations of the precursor appeared to be elevated because the labeled compounds were fed to plants without reducing the endogenous levels of these precursors. By inhibiting each isoprenoid pathway and monitoring the phenotypic changes at different doses of the labeled precursors, we were able to estimate the status of isoprenoid pathways. This helped us to predict whether the feeding experiments were done under physiologically relevant conditions. Our results showed that the concentrations of [2-13C]DX in the media can greatly affect the ratio of 13C labels in the products (Table III). Thus, the 13C incorporation determined in different feeding experiments must be carefully interpreted. When the MEP pathway is limiting in the cla1−1 seedlings at 0.2 mm DX (judged by the incomplete recovery of thecla1−1 phenotype; Fig. 2 A), the incorporation of [2-13C]DX into ent-kaurene was only 68%, whereas it increased to 87% at a higher [2-13C]DX concentration. It is unclear at present whether the reduced labeling ratio at the lower dose of [2-13C]DX is due to the leaky nature of the cla1−1 mutant (e.g. presence of isozymes) or to the crossover from the MVA pathway. These observations indicate that the amount of 13C incorporation into the product does not necessarily reflect the relative contribution of each pathway under normal growth conditions. These results also suggest that the relative contribution of each isoprenoid pathway could vary when either pathway is up- or down-regulated during plant development or in response to environmental conditions. Nevertheless, we postulate that the MEP and MVA pathways play a major role in the biosynthesis of ent-kaurene and campesterol, respectively, in Arabidopsis seedlings. When incubated with 0.8 mm [2-13C]DX, 87% of the C5units of ent-kaurene came from [2-13C]DX, whereas DX fed under the same conditions provided only 7% of the isoprene units to campesterol. This demonstrates that the MEP pathway is not the primary route for the biosynthesis of campesterol. Similarly, we can conclude that the MVA pathway plays a minor role in the formation of ent-kaurene based on the much lower incorporation of [2-13C]MVL into ent-kaurene relative to that into campesterol (Table III). Our current study provides a new view regarding the crossover between two isoprenoid pathways. The incorporation of MVL intoent-kaurene was still observed when the growth inhibition caused by mevastatin was not fully restored by MVL. In this situation, the MVA pathway is likely to be limiting, whereas there is no obvious reason that the MEP pathway is inhibited. Therefore, it appears that [2-13C]MVL can be incorporated intoent-kaurene against a concentration gradient. To better understand this problem, the common isoprenoid intermediate(s) (e.g. IPP, DMAPP, or geranylgeranyl diphosphate) responsible for the crossover between two isoprenoid pathways needs to be determined. An active uptake of IPP into isolated plastids in a facilitated-diffusion manner (43Kreuz K. Kleinig H. Eur. J. Biochem. 1984; 141: 531-535Google Scholar, 44Bauerle R. Lutke-Brinkhaus F. Ortmann B. Berger S. Kleinig H. Planta. 1990; 181: 229-233Google Scholar, 45Soler E. Clastre M. Bantignies B. Marigo G. Ambid C. Planta. 1993; 191: 324-329Google Scholar) implies that IPP may be involved in the precursor exchange between the MVA and MEP pathways. It is interesting to note that the cla1−1 phenotype was rescued only partially even at a high dose of MVL (Fig. 2 C). This demonstrates that the MEP pathway is still required for normal plant growth even when the flux of MVA pathway is elevated. Taken together, our current data suggest that the uptake of an intermediate from the MVA pathway into the isoprenoid pathway in plastids does occur, but that this mechanism is not sufficient to fully complement the defect in the MEP pathway. This also appears to be true for the other direction, uptake from the MEP pathway to the MVA pathway. We noted that the incorporation of labeled precursors intoent-kaurene and campesterol was greater in our first set of experiments performed in 3% sucrose than in the second set in 1% sucrose. This observation suggests that sucrose concentrations may affect the uptake of 13C-labeled substrates by plants and/or the status of two isoprenoid pathways. In summary, our study showed that both isoprenoid pathways are involved in the biosynthesis of GAs, which are growth-promoting hormones in plants. We predict that the relative contribution of each pathway may be modulated during plant development, by environmental cues and by the status of the other pathway. Molecular genetic approaches in the model species Arabidopsis would be useful to uncover how each isoprenoid pathway is regulated and whether the crossover plays any role in controlling isoprenoid biosynthesis in cytoplasm and plastids. Cohesin is a conserved multiprotein complex that plays an essential role in sister chromatid cohesion. During interphase, cohesin is required for the establishment of cohesion following DNA replication. Because cohesin mutants resulted in increased sensitivity to DNA damage, a role for cohesin in DNA repair was also suggested. However, it was unclear whether this was due to general perturbation of cohesion or whether cohesin has a specialized role at the damage site. We therefore used a laser microbeam to create DNA damage at discrete sites in the cell nucleus and observed specificin vivo assembly of proteins at these sites by immunofluorescent detection. We observed that human cohesin is recruited to the damage site immediately after damage induction. Analysis of mutant cells revealed that cohesin recruitment to the damage site is dependent on the DNA double-strand break repair factor Mre11/Rad50 but not ATM or Nbs1. Consistently, Mre11/Rad50 and cohesin interact with each other in an interphase-specific manner. This interaction peaks in S/G2 phase, during which cohesin is recruited to the DNA damage. Our results demonstrate the S/G2-specific and Mre11/Rad50-dependent recruitment of human cohesin to DNA damage, suggesting a specialized subfunction for cohesin in cell cycle-specific DNA double strand break repair. Cohesin is a conserved multiprotein complex that plays an essential role in sister chromatid cohesion. During interphase, cohesin is required for the establishment of cohesion following DNA replication. Because cohesin mutants resulted in increased sensitivity to DNA damage, a role for cohesin in DNA repair was also suggested. However, it was unclear whether this was due to general perturbation of cohesion or whether cohesin has a specialized role at the damage site. We therefore used a laser microbeam to create DNA damage at discrete sites in the cell nucleus and observed specificin vivo assembly of proteins at these sites by immunofluorescent detection. We observed that human cohesin is recruited to the damage site immediately after damage induction. Analysis of mutant cells revealed that cohesin recruitment to the damage site is dependent on the DNA double-strand break repair factor Mre11/Rad50 but not ATM or Nbs1. Consistently, Mre11/Rad50 and cohesin interact with each other in an interphase-specific manner. This interaction peaks in S/G2 phase, during which cohesin is recruited to the DNA damage. Our results demonstrate the S/G2-specific and Mre11/Rad50-dependent recruitment of human cohesin to DNA damage, suggesting a specialized subfunction for cohesin in cell cycle-specific DNA double strand break repair. DNA double strand breaks (DSBs) 1The abbreviations used are: DSB, double strand break; NHEJ, nonhomologous end joining; HR, homologous recombination; SMC, structural maintenance ofchromosomes; A-T, ataxia-telangiectasia; ATLD, ataxia-telangiectasia-like disorder; NBS, Nijmegen breakage syndrome; NuMA, nuclear mitotic apparatus; h, human; IRIF, ionizing radiation-induced foci. occur during normal DNA replication and can also be induced by exogenous agents such as gamma irradiation. Two pathways have evolved to repair DSBs: nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ), which is error-prone; and homologous recombination (HR), which is error-free (for review, see Refs. 1Khanna K.K. Jackson S.P. Nat. Genet. 2001; 27: 247-254Google Scholarand 2Haber J.E. Trends Genet. 2000; 16: 259-264Google Scholar). Because HR prefers the homologous sister chromatid as a template, HR repair is the main pathway for postreplicative repair during late S/G2 phase, whereas NHEJ is utilized in G1/early S phase. NHEJ and HR require distinct sets of factors, except for the trimeric complex Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 that appears to be involved in an early step in both NHEJ and HR. Mre11, Rad50, and Nbs1 are essential proteins in mammals, and they play critical roles in both cell cycle checkpoint activation and DNA repair (3Luo G. Yao M.S. Bender C.F. Mills M. Bladl A.R. Bradley A. Petrini J.H.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 7376-7381Google Scholar, 4Xiao Y. Weaver D.T. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 2985-2991Google Scholar, 5Zhu J. Petersen S. Tessarollo L. Nussenzweig A. Curr. Biol. 2001; 11: 105-109Google Scholar). Unlike Nbs1, Mre11 and Rad50 are conserved between yeast and mammals and are able to form a subcomplex (Mre-Rad50) (6de Jager M. van Noort J. van Gent D.C. Dekker C. Kanaar R. Wyman C. Mol. Cell. 2001; 8: 1129-1135Google Scholar). Mre11 is an exo- and endonuclease, whereas Rad50 has a coiled-coil structure with an ATPase motif, distantly related to thestructural maintenance ofchromosomes (SMC) family of proteins. Although Nbs1 is not absolutely required in vitro, DNA binding and the enzymatic activity of Mre11-Rad50 are enhanced in the presence of Nbs1 (7Paull T.T. Gellert M. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 1276-1288Google Scholar). Thus, Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 most likely plays an important role in DNA end processing for subsequent repair. ATM (ataxia-telangiectasia, mutated), a member of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase family, is a major DSB signal transducer and is critical for activating G1/S, S, and G2/M checkpoints upon DNA damage. ATM was found to phosphorylate Nbs1 upon DSB induction, which is required for the DNA damage response by Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 (8Wu X. Ranganathan V. Weisman D.S. Heine W.F. Ciccone D.N. O'Neill T.B. Crick K.E. Pierce K.A. Lane W.S. Rathbun G. Livingston D.M. Weaver D.T. Nature. 2000; 405: 477-481Google Scholar, 9Zhao S. Weng Y.-C. Yuan S.-S.F. Lin Y.-T. Hsu H.-C. Lin S.-C.J. Gerbino E. Song M.-H. Zdzienicka M.Z. Gatti R.A. Shay J.W. Ziv Y. Shiloh Y. Lee E.Y.-H.P. Nature. 2000; 405: 473-477Google Scholar). ATM is mutated in patients with the pleiotropic genetic disorder ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T) (10Shiloh Y. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 2001; 11: 71-77Google Scholar). A-T cells exhibit sensitivity to ionizing irradiation, chromosome instability, and radioresistant DNA synthesis, an S phase checkpoint defect. Mutations in Mre11 and Nbs1 were found in AT-like disorder (ATLD) and Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS), respectively (11Carney J.P. Maser R.S. Olivares H. Davis E.M. Le Beau M. Yates 3rd, J.R. Hays L. Morgan W.F. Petrini J.H. Cell. 1998; 93: 477-486Google Scholar, 12Stewart G.S. Maser R.S. Stankovic T. Bressan D.A. Kaplan M.I. Jaspers N.G.J. Raams A. Byrd P.J. Petrini J.H. Taylor A.M.R. Cell. 1999; 99: 577-587Google Scholar, 13Varon R. Vissinga C. Platzer M. Cerosaletti K.M. Chrzanowska K.H. Saar K. Beckmann G. Seemanova E. Cooper P.R. Nowak N.J. Stumm M. Weemaes C.M.R. Gatti R.A. Wilson R.K. Digweed M. Rosenthal A. Sperling K. Concannon P. Reis A. Cell. 1998; 93: 467-476Google Scholar). These two diseases also share similar cellular phenotypes with A-T. Cohesin is a conserved protein complex essential for sister chromatid cohesion and chromosome segregation. It contains two SMC family proteins, SMC1 and SMC3, and the non-SMC components Rad21 (Scc1/Mcd1) and SA1/SA2 (Scc3) (14Hirano T. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2000; 69: 115-144Google Scholar). SMC1 and SMC3 also exist as a free heterodimer in the cell, the function of which is not clear (15Losada A. Hirano M. Hirano T. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 1986-1997Google Scholar). In vertebrates, a majority of cohesin associates with chromosomal DNA in an interphase-specific manner. This association peaks during S phase, with subsequent dissociation during late G2/prophase and reassociation in telophase (15Losada A. Hirano M. Hirano T. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 1986-1997Google Scholar, 16Gregson H.C. Schmiesing J.A. Kim J.-S. Kobayashi T. Zhou S. Yokomori K. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 47575-47582Google Scholar, 17Sumara I. Vorlaufer E. Gieffers C. Peters B.H. Peters J.-M. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 151: 749-761Google Scholar). Cohesin is required for the establishment of sister chromatid cohesion following DNA replication (15Losada A. Hirano M. Hirano T. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 1986-1997Google Scholar). The potential function of cohesin in the DNA damage response was suggested by the original identification of the cohesin component Rad21 in Schizosaccharomyces pombe as one of the Rad genes, whose mutation makes the cell sensitive to DSBs (18Birkenbihl R.P. Subramani S. Nucleic Acids Res. 1992; 25: 6605-6611Google Scholar). Rad21 depletion in a vertebrate was also associated with increased radiation sensitivity (19Sonoda E. Matsusaka T. Morrison C. Vagnarelli P. Hoshi O. Ushiki T. Nojima K. Fukagawa T. Waizenegger I.C. Peters J.M. Earnshaw W.C. Takeda S. Dev. Cell. 2001; 1: 759-770Google Scholar). In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, cohesin was shown to be required for postreplicative DSB repair (20Sjögren C. Nasmyth K. Curr. Biol. 2001; 11: 991-995Google Scholar). It was suggested that sister chromatid cohesion is required for homologous recombination. However, it was unclear whether the effect of cohesin on DNA repair was through its genome-wide cohesion function or through a specialized role at the damage sites. In this article, we demonstrate the specific recruitment of human cohesin to DSB damage and its interaction with DSB repair factors, suggesting its direct role in DNA damage recognition and repair. A specific region of a submicroliter volume inside the cell nucleus was irradiated by focusing a second harmonic (532 nm) of a pulsed neodymium:ytrium aluminum garnet laser within the selected Z plane through an epifluorescence port of a Zeiss LSM 410 confocal system. An approximately 5-μm line was scanned continuously for 2 min. System parameters used (2–3 μJ/pulse energy after 100× Ph3, numerical aperture 1.3 oil immersion Zeiss Neofluar objective, 4–6-ns pulse duration, 7.5 Hz) are similar to those used for mitotic chromosome cutting or nuclear body ablation and correspond to irradiances 2–3 times higher than the estimated threshold values of optical breakdown in water (21Venugopalan V. Guerra III, A. Nahen K. Vogel A. Phys. Rev. Lett. 2002; 88: 078103Google Scholar, 22Krasieva T.B. Chapman C.F. LaMorte V.J. Venugopalan V. Tromberg B.J. Proc. Soc. Photo-opt. Instrum. Eng. 1998; 3260: 38-44Google Scholar). After microirradiation, cells were fixed and stained with antibodies against various proteins. Typically 4–6 cells/plate, using up to seven plates, were microirradiated and fixed within 3–20 min post-irradiation. Cell viability was confirmed by morphology. At least three independent experiments were carried out for different cells and cell cycle stages. Staining was repeated multiple times for each antibody. HeLa cells, the wild-type human fibroblast IMR-90 (American Type Culture Collection), and Mre11 mutant fibroblasts derived from an ATLD patient (ATLD2(D6867) (12Stewart G.S. Maser R.S. Stankovic T. Bressan D.A. Kaplan M.I. Jaspers N.G.J. Raams A. Byrd P.J. Petrini J.H. Taylor A.M.R. Cell. 1999; 99: 577-587Google Scholar)) were used. The human A-T fibroblast cell line (GM02052D) and NBS fibroblast cell line (GM07166) were obtained from the Coriell Cell Repositories. HeLa cells were synchronized to the S and G2phases by a double thymidine block and to M and G1 phases by an additional nocodazole treatment as described previously (23Schmiesing J.A. Gregson H.C. Zhou S. Yokomori K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 6996-7006Google Scholar). Synchronization efficiency was typically more than 90% (16Gregson H.C. Schmiesing J.A. Kim J.-S. Kobayashi T. Zhou S. Yokomori K. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 47575-47582Google Scholar). For laser microirradiation of G1 cells, synchronized mitotic cells were marked on gridded coverslips, continuously observed to confirm their division, and subjected to laser microirradiation 5 h after the nocodazole release. Antigen affinity-purified rabbit polyclonal antibodies against hSMC1, hSMC3, SA1 (cross-reactive to SA2), and CNAP1 were described previously (16Gregson H.C. Schmiesing J.A. Kim J.-S. Kobayashi T. Zhou S. Yokomori K. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 47575-47582Google Scholar, 23Schmiesing J.A. Gregson H.C. Zhou S. Yokomori K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 6996-7006Google Scholar). Mouse monoclonal antibodies specific for Mre11, Rad50, ATM, BRCA1, and Rad51 (GeneTex), Nbs1 (BD Biosciences), poly(ADP-ribose)polymerase (PARP; Trevigen), NuMA (Oncogene Research Products), and anti-acetylated histone H4 polyclonal antibody (Upstate Biotechnology) were used. Donkey anti-mouse IgG conjugated to Alexa-488 or Alexa-546 and goat anti-rabbit IgG conjugated to Alexa-546 were from Molecular Probes. Cells were fixed and stained as described (23Schmiesing J.A. Gregson H.C. Zhou S. Yokomori K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 6996-7006Google Scholar). Broken DNA ends were labeled with BrdUrd in the presence of terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase and visualized with Alexa 488-conjugated mouse anti-BrdUrd monoclonal antibody as described previously (24Nelms B.E. Maser R.S. MacKay J.F. Lagally M.G. Petrini J.H. Science. 1998; 280: 590-592Google Scholar). Immunofluorescent images were captured using a laser-scanning confocal microscope (Zeiss LSM 410). Coimmunoprecipitation was performed as described previously (16Gregson H.C. Schmiesing J.A. Kim J.-S. Kobayashi T. Zhou S. Yokomori K. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 47575-47582Google Scholar). Preimmune IgG was used as a negative control. The antibody-protein complex on protein A beads was washed in HEMG buffer (25 mm HEPES (pH 7.6), 12.5 mmMgCl2, 0.1 mm EDTA, 10% glycerol) containing 0.1 or 0.5 m KCl in the presence of 0.1% Nonidet P-40. Bound proteins were eluted from the beads with 2 mguanidine-HCl. Proteins were precipitated with trichloroacetic acid and separated by SDS-PAGE followed by Western blot analysis. Immunoprecipitations were also carried out in the presence of 300 μg of ethidium bromide (EtBr)/ml to remove contaminating DNA as described previously (23Schmiesing J.A. Gregson H.C. Zhou S. Yokomori K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 6996-7006Google Scholar). We first determined whether it was possible to introduce DNA damage at a discrete site in the cell nucleus by focusing a visible 532 nm pulsed neodymium:ytrium laser microbeam to a selected Z plane of less than 1 μm in depth. The cell membranes of the irradiated cells were intact, and cells remained viable during the experiments. We observed their viability up to 30 h post-irradiation (data not shown). The presence of the DNA breaks was detected by terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase-mediated BrdUrd incorporation at the broken DNA ends (Fig. 1 A). After microirradiation, cells were fixed within 3–20 min and stained with antibodies against various proteins to determine their immediate recruitment. Consistent with the published results using γ-irradiation, the factors known to recognize DSBs, including Mre11, Rad50, Ku, BRCA1, and poly(ADP-ribose)polymerase-1, clustered to the damage site (24Nelms B.E. Maser R.S. MacKay J.F. Lagally M.G. Petrini J.H. Science. 1998; 280: 590-592Google Scholar, 25Paull T.T. Rogakou E.P. Yamazaki V. Kirchgessner C.U. Gellert M. Bonner W.M. Curr. Biol. 2000; 10: 886-895Google Scholar, 26Wood R.D. Mitchell M. Sgouros J. Lindahl T. Science. 2001; 291: 1284-1289Google Scholar). Recruitment of ATM was also observed. In contrast, no enrichment for CNAP1, acetylated histone H4, or thenuclear mitotic apparatus protein (NuMA) was detected at the sites of damage. CNAP1 (or hCAP-D2/Eg7) is a component of condensin, a different SMC-containing complex that is required for chromosome condensation (23Schmiesing J.A. Gregson H.C. Zhou S. Yokomori K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 6996-7006Google Scholar, 27Kimura K. Cuvier O. Hirano T. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 5417-5420Google Scholar) and recently shown to play a role in UV damage repair (28Aono N. Sutani T. Tomonaga T. Mochida S. Yanagida M. Nature. 2002; 417: 197-202Google Scholar). NuMA is a nuclear matrix-associated protein (29Lydersen B.K. Pettijohn D.E. Cell. 1980; 22: 489-499Google Scholar). We found that upon microirradiation, the damaged site transiently changed its optical property and appeared as a distinct line. This served as a marker for the damage site (Fig.1 A). Duration of its appearance, however, did not correlate with recruited protein localization (data not shown). Taken together, our method allows detection of in vivo factor recruitment to a DNA damage site. Using this system, we tested the potential recruitment of cohesin to the laser-induced damage. Cohesin was recruited to the damage sites, which was detected by antibodies against both SMC (hSMC1) and non-SMC (SA1/SA2) components of cohesin to distinguish from the free SMC heterodimer (Fig. 1 B). Similar recruitment was observed in both HeLa and nontransformed human fibroblast IMR-90 cells (Figs.1 B and 2 A). Thus, this is not a cancer cell-specific phenomenon. We further tested cohesin localization in mutant fibroblast cells derived from A-T, NBS, and ATLD patients. Cohesin and Mre11-Rad50 recruitment to the damage site was unaffected in A-T cells (Fig. 2 B). Recruitment of Mre11-Rad50 to the damage site in A-T cells is consistent with a recent report using γ-irradiation (30Mirzoeva O.K. Petrini J.H.J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 281-288Google Scholar). Furthermore, both cohesin and Mre11-Rad50 were efficiently recruited to the damaged sites in NBS cells (Fig. 2 C). In contrast, cohesin failed to cluster at the damage site in the Mre11-mutated ATLD2 cells (Fig. 2 D). In these cells, the level of Rad50 is also down-regulated, likely due to a secondary effect of the mutation of Mre11 (12Stewart G.S. Maser R.S. Stankovic T. Bressan D.A. Kaplan M.I. Jaspers N.G.J. Raams A. Byrd P.J. Petrini J.H. Taylor A.M.R. Cell. 1999; 99: 577-587Google Scholar). These results indicate that Mre11 or Rad50 (or both) plays a crucial role in recruitment of cohesin to the sites of DNA damage. Consistent with the requirement of Mre11-Rad50 for cohesin recruitment to DNA damage, there is a specific in vivo interaction between cohesin and Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50. Coimmunoprecipitation of the endogenous proteins in the nuclear extract of undamaged asynchronous HeLa cells revealed that anti-Rad50 antibody coprecipitated hSMC1 in a 0.5 m KCl-resistant manner (Fig. 3 A). Rad51, an eukaryotic RecA homologue involved in the HR pathway of DSB repair, was also shown to be recruited to the DNA damage (31Tashiro S. Walter J. Shinohara A. Kamada N. Cremer T. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 150: 283-291Google Scholar). However, anti-Rad51 failed to coprecipitate hSMC1 in this experiment, supporting the specificity of the interaction between Rad50 (Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50) and hSMC1 (cohesin) (Fig. 3 A). This interaction was further confirmed by reciprocal immunoprecipitation with antibodies specific for hSMC1 and hSMC3, both of which coprecipitated Rad50, whereas preimmune IgG did not (Fig. 3 B). EtBr treatment of the sample did not affect the interaction, demonstrating that the interaction between cohesin and Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 is not mediated by DNA (Fig. 3 C). This is consistent with the notion that Rad51 is also a DNA-binding protein but fails to interact with cohesin (Fig.3 A). Some cohesin was found in the 0.5 m KCl wash fraction, whereas Mre11 was exclusively in the 0.5 mKCl-resistant eluate of the Rad50 coimmunoprecipitation, indicating that not all cohesin tightly associates with Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 (Fig.3 C). The interaction between cohesin and Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 was also observed in human fibroblasts (Fig. 3 D). Anti-Rad50 antibody coprecipitated cohesin and Mre11 in both NBS and A-T cells, indicating that cohesin is capable of interacting with Mre11-Rad50 in the absence of the wild-type Nbs1 or ATM. This finding is consistent with the observed recruitment of both Mre11-Rad50 and cohesin to DNA damage in these cells (Fig. 2, B and C). In synchronized HeLa cells, the interaction between cohesin and Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 was shown to be interphase-specific even though both complexes are present during mitosis (Fig. 3 E) (16Gregson H.C. Schmiesing J.A. Kim J.-S. Kobayashi T. Zhou S. Yokomori K. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 47575-47582Google Scholar). The interaction exists in cells most abundantly in S/G2 phases without any exogenous damage induction, correlating with the peak of chromatin association and sister chromatid cohesion function of cohesin (15Losada A. Hirano M. Hirano T. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 1986-1997Google Scholar, 16Gregson H.C. Schmiesing J.A. Kim J.-S. Kobayashi T. Zhou S. Yokomori K. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 47575-47582Google Scholar). A similar interaction pattern was seen with ATM (Fig.3 E). Interestingly, cohesin recruitment to the site of damage coincides with the peak of its interaction with Mre11-Rad50 in S/G2phases. Upon laser damage induction in synchronized HeLa cells at G1, S, or G2 phase, the recruitment of Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 was observed in both G1 and S/G2 phases, consistent with its involvement in both NHEJ and HR (Fig. 4). However, cohesin recruitment to damage is limited to S and G2 phases, but not in G1 phase, suggesting that cohesin is active for DNA damage recognition in an S/G2-specific fashion. These results indicate that cohesin requires an S/G2-specific factor(s) or modification(s), in addition to Mre11-Rad50, for its recruitment to DNA damage. These results suggest that cohesin specifically participates in the DSB damage response in S/G2 phase, possibly in the HR but not the NHEJ pathway. Laser microbeams (optical scissors) as well as optical tweezers made it possible to micromanipulate or ablate cells or subcellular structures, including chromosomes, in a highly specific manner (32Berns M.W. Tadir Y. Liang H. Tromberg B. Methods Cell Biol. 1998; 55: 71-98Google Scholar). Our results demonstrate that tightly focused visible light (532 nm) of a pulsed neodymium:ytrium aluminum garnet laser induces DNA breaks at a defined region in the cell nucleus and evokes DSB repair factor recruitment to the site of damage. Several other methods were previously developed to introduce DNA damage in a defined region in the nucleus. A study using partial volume irradiation, in which the cell was γ-irradiated in a striped pattern using a gridded shield, demonstrated for the first time the recruitment of Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 to the sites of DNA damage as early as 30 min after irradiation (24Nelms B.E. Maser R.S. MacKay J.F. Lagally M.G. Petrini J.H. Science. 1998; 280: 590-592Google Scholar). However, this method did not allow monitoring at the earlier time points during which DNA damage recognition and initial factor recruitment take place. An alternative technique of inducing damage using ultraviolet (UV) microirradiation in the presence of bromodeoxyuridine (BrdUrd) was recently shown to induce DSBs efficiently at specific sites in the nucleus. This damage was accompanied by recruitment of several DNA repair proteins including Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50, BRCA1, and Rad51 (25Paull T.T. Rogakou E.P. Yamazaki V. Kirchgessner C.U. Gellert M. Bonner W.M. Curr. Biol. 2000; 10: 886-895Google Scholar, 31Tashiro S. Walter J. Shinohara A. Kamada N. Cremer T. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 150: 283-291Google Scholar, 33Rogakou E.P. Boon C. Redon C. Bonner W.M. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 146: 905-915Google Scholar). However, the presence of a halogenated thymidine analogue and the secondary effects of UV have to be taken into consideration. In our method, which does not require any chromophore or other exogenous agent, collateral damage is minimal because the visible green light used is harmless in the unfocused areas due to its insufficient energy density. Thus, this method provides a useful tool to dissect the immediate damage response in the cell. Using this system, we observed that a subpopulation of cohesin is recruited to sites of damage in an Mre11-Rad50 (but not Nbs1)-dependent and S/G2-specific manner in human cells. Recently, hSMC1 was shown to be phosphorylated by ATM in an Nbs1-dependent manner upon DSB induction and to participate in S phase checkpoint control (34Kim S.-T. Xu B. Kastan M.B. Genes Dev. 2002; 16: 560-570Google Scholar, 35Yazdi P.T. Wang Y. Zhao S. Patel N. Lee E.Y.-H.P. Qin J. Genes Dev. 2002; 16: 571-582Google Scholar). However, our results revealed that the initial damage recognition/recruitment of cohesin is independent of this process. The DNA damage response defects in A-T and NBS cells are not due to the impairment of cohesin or Mre11-Rad50 recruitment to DNA damage, suggesting that ATM and Nbs1 are not required for the initial recruitment of Mre11-Rad50 or cohesin to DNA damage sites. This finding was somewhat surprising, as Mre11-Rad50 was mislocalized in NBS cells and failed to form ionizing radiation-induced foci (IRIF), which was thought to be indicative of the lack of recruitment of Mre11-Rad50 to the DNA damage sites (11Carney J.P. Maser R.S. Olivares H. Davis E.M. Le Beau M. Yates 3rd, J.R. Hays L. Morgan W.F. Petrini J.H. Cell. 1998; 93: 477-486Google Scholar). However, impairment of IRIF formation in NBS cells was observed at later time points when the vast majority of DSB repair is complete (11Carney J.P. Maser R.S. Olivares H. Davis E.M. Le Beau M. Yates 3rd, J.R. Hays L. Morgan W.F. Petrini J.H. Cell. 1998; 93: 477-486Google Scholar). Thus, late-forming IRIF may not be an ideal indicator of the immediate DNA damage response. Furthermore, our data are not inconsistent with the previous in vitro observation that Mre11 and Rad50 forms a stable complex in the absence of Nbs1 and tethers DNA ends (6de Jager M. van Noort J. van Gent D.C. Dekker C. Kanaar R. Wyman C. Mol. Cell. 2001; 8: 1129-1135Google Scholar). Because Nbs1 is important for ATP-driven DNA unwinding and the endonuclease activity of Mre11-Rad50 in vitro (7Paull T.T. Gellert M. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 1276-1288Google Scholar), it is possible that the recruited Mre11-Rad50 may be unstable or functionally compromised in NBS cells. An alternative but not mutually exclusive possibility is that the primary role of Nbs1 is to transduce checkpoint signals rather than to be involved in actual DNA repair in somatic cells, and that the increased radiation sensitivity of the mutant cells is caused primarily by the checkpoint defect. The interaction between cohesin and Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 occurs in the absence of exogenously induced DNA damage. A role for Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 in the repair of DNA damage that arises during normal DNA replication has been suggested (36Maser R.S. Mirzoeva O.K. Wells J. OLIVARES H. Williams B.R. Zinkel R.A. Farnham P.J. Petrini J.H.J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 6006-6016Google Scholar). Because the interaction peaks during S/G2 phases, it is tempting to speculate that cohesin plays a role in the housekeeping DNA repair process together with Mre11-Nbs1-Rad50 under normal conditions. Depletion of cohesin in chicken cells led to chromosome instability in the absence of DNA damaging agents (19Sonoda E. Matsusaka T. Morrison C. Vagnarelli P. Hoshi O. Ushiki T. Nojima K. Fukagawa T. Waizenegger I.C. Peters J.M. Earnshaw W.C. Takeda S. Dev. Cell. 2001; 1: 759-770Google Scholar), which may have been caused by impairment of such a housekeeping DNA repair mechanism in addition to segregation defects. What is the function of cohesin at the DNA damage sites? It was shown that cohesin binds to DNA and stimulates intermolecular ligation of linear DNA molecules in the presence of DNA ligase in vitro(37Losada A. Hirano T. Curr. Biol. 2001; 11: 268-272Google Scholar). Thus, cohesin may facilitate the DNA repair process by forming protein-DNA aggregates and promoting interaction of the broken ends of DNA. However, this does not fully explain why cohesin recruitment is S/G2-specific despite the association of cohesin with chromatin DNA in G1 at a level comparable with that in G2 in human cells (16Gregson H.C. Schmiesing J.A. Kim J.-S. Kobayashi T. Zhou S. Yokomori K. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 47575-47582Google Scholar). Alternatively, it is conceivable that cohesin is involved strictly in DSB checkpoint control as suggested by the recent finding of a link between hSMC1 phosphorylation and S phase checkpoint activation (34Kim S.-T. Xu B. Kastan M.B. Genes Dev. 2002; 16: 560-570Google Scholar, 35Yazdi P.T. Wang Y. Zhao S. Patel N. Lee E.Y.-H.P. Qin J. Genes Dev. 2002; 16: 571-582Google Scholar). However, the role of the recruited cohesin in G2 phase is less clear, as a study in yeast showed that cohesin is not involved in G2/M checkpoint control (20Sjögren C. Nasmyth K. Curr. Biol. 2001; 11: 991-995Google Scholar). Because cohesin is active in sister chromatid cohesion during this time, it is also possible that cohesin is recruited to establish local cohesion de novo at damage sites and to bring the homologous regions of the sister chromatids together to promote the HR process (Fig.5). The system described in the current study will be useful in further investigation of the molecular requirement for cohesin targeting and function at the damage site and in dissecting the process of DSB recognition and factor assembly in mammalian cells. We thank Alex Ball, Jr. for critical reading of the manuscript.

Expression of the tryptophanase operon of Escherichia coli is regulated by catabolite repression and tryptophan-induced transcription antitermination. An induction site activated by l-tryptophan is created in the translating ribosome during synthesis of TnaC, the 24-residue leader peptide. Replacing the tnaC stop codon with a tryptophan codon allows tryptophan-charged tryptophan transfer RNA to substitute for tryptophan as inducer. This suggests that the ribosomal A site occupied by the tryptophanyl moiety of the charged transfer RNA is the site of induction. The location of tryptophan-12 of nascent TnaC in the peptide exit tunnel was crucial for induction. These results show that a nascent peptide sequence can influence translation continuation and termination within a translating ribosome.

Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar observations of surface deformation due to the 1999 Hector Mine earthquake reveal motion on several nearby faults of the eastern California shear zone. We document both vertical and horizontal displacements of several millimeters to several centimeters across kilometer-wide zones centered on pre-existing faults. Portions of some faults experienced retrograde (that is, opposite to their long-term geologic slip) motion during or shortly after the earthquake. The observed deformation likely represents elastic response of compliant fault zones to the permanent co-seismic stress changes. The induced fault displacements imply decreases in the effective shear modulus within the kilometer-wide fault zones, indicating that the latter are mechanically distinct from the ambient crustal rocks.

The Plasmodium falciparum serine repeat antigen (SERA) has shown considerable promise as a blood stage vaccine for the control of malaria. A related protein, SERPH, has also been described in P. falciparum. Whereas their biological role remains unknown, both proteins possess papain-like protease domains that may provide attractive targets for therapeutic intervention. Genomic sequencing has recently shown thatSERA and SERPH are the fifth and sixth genes, respectively, in a cluster of eight SERA homologues present on chromosome 2. In this paper, the expression and functional relevance of these eight genes and of a ninth SERA homologue found on chromosome 9 were examined in blood stage parasites. Using reverse transcriptase-PCR and microarray approaches, we demonstrate that whereas mRNA to all nine SERA genes is synthesized late in the erythrocytic cycle, it is those genes in the central region of the chromosome 2 cluster that are substantially up-regulated at this time. Using antibodies specific to each SERA, it was apparent that SERA4 to -6, and possibly also SERA9, are synthesized in blood stage parasites. The reactivity of antibodies from malaria-immune individuals with the SERA recombinant proteins suggested that SERA2 and SERA3 are also expressed at least in some parasite populations. To examine whether SERA genes are essential to blood stage growth, each of the eight chromosome 2 SERA genes was targeted for disruption. Whereas genes at the periphery of the cluster were mostly dispensable (SERA2 and -3 andSERA7 and -8), those in the central region (SERA4 to -6) could not be disrupted. The inability to disrupt SERA4, -5, and -6 is consistent with their apparent dominant expression and implies an important role for these genes in maintenance of the erythrocytic cycle. The inability to disrupt SERA4, -5, and -6 is consistent with their apparent dominant expression and implies an important role for these genes in maintenance of the erythrocytic cycle. Malaria remains one of the most devastating diseases of mankind. It has been estimated that there are as many as 500 million clinical cases of malaria each year including 1–2 million deaths. The emergence of widespread drug-resistant parasites and insecticide-resistant vectors has intensified the need for novel drug target strategies and an effective vaccine. Parasitol. 1991; 44: 1-13Google Scholar). This gene, termedSERPH, encodes a protein that is also localized to the parasitophorous vacuole and that has very similar characteristics to SERA, including the presence of a centrally located papain-like protease domain. The likely presence of at least one otherSERA gene homologue has also been reported (10Fox B.A. Bzik D.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1994; 68: 133-144Google Scholar). Recently, nucleotide sequencing of P. falciparum chromosome 2 identified the presence of eight SERA-like genes located in a cluster in a central region of the chromosome (24Gardner M.J. Tettelin H. Carucci D.J. Cummings L.M. Aravind L. Koonin E.V. Shallom S. Mason T. Yu K. Fujii C. Pederson J. Shen K. Jing J. Aston C. Lai Z. Schwartz D.C. Pertea M. Salzberg S. Zhou L. Sutton G.G. Clayton R. White O. Smith H.O. Fraser C.M. Hoffman S.L. et al.Science. 1998; 282: 1126-1132Google Scholar). TheseSERA genes are arranged in a head-to-tail array withSERA and SERPH the fifth and sixth genes in the cluster, respectively. A similar cluster of five SERA -like genes has been identified in Plasmodium vivax (25Kiefer M.C. Crawford K.A. Boley L.J. Landsberg K.E. Gibson H.L. Kaslow D.C. Barr P.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1996; 78: 55-65Google Scholar), and further homologues have been discovered in the rodent malaria parasite Plasmodium vinckei (26Gor D.O. Li A.C. Rosenthal P.J. Vaccine. 1998; 16: 1193-1202Google Scholar). The presence of relatively large SERA multigene families in divergentPlasmodium species suggests an important biological role for the proteins encoded by these genes. Whereas all the SERA proteins are predicted to possess a central domain with strong homology with the papain family of cysteine proteases, some, including SERA itself, were found to contain a highly unusual cysteine to serine substitution in the active site position (6Eakin A.E. Higaki J.N. McKerrow J.H. Craik C.S. Nature. 1989; 342: 132Google Scholar, 7Higgins D.G. McConnell D.J. Sharp P.M. Nature. 1989; 340: 604Google Scholar, 24Gardner M.J. Tettelin H. Carucci D.J. Cummings L.M. Aravind L. Koonin E.V. Shallom S. Mason T. Yu K. Fujii C. Pederson J. Shen K. Jing J. Aston C. Lai Z. Schwartz D.C. Pertea M. Salzberg S. Zhou L. Sutton G.G. Clayton R. White O. Smith H.O. Fraser C.M. Hoffman S.L. et al.Science. 1998; 282: 1126-1132Google Scholar). Furthermore, in certain P. vivax and P. vinckeiSERA homologues, substitutions were observed in other important catalytic site residues, raising the possibility that at least some of these molecules may no longer function as proteases (25Kiefer M.C. Crawford K.A. Boley L.J. Landsberg K.E. Gibson H.L. Kaslow D.C. Barr P.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1996; 78: 55-65Google Scholar). Importantly, however, the protease domain of some SERA homologues, including SERPH, have no such substitutions. Very little is known about the function of the SERA proteins, and the fundamental reason for the requirement of so many homologues is unknown. In this paper, we analyze the expression of the eight chromosome 2 SERA genes using a combination of RT-PCR, microarray, antigenicity studies and gene “knockout” approaches. We also identify and similarly characterize a ninth SERAhomologue present on P. falciparum chromosome 9. These studies reveal that genes in the central region of the chromosome 2 cluster, but not those toward the periphery, are expressed in mature blood stage forms and appear to play an important role in maintenance of the erythrocytic cycle. Biochem. Parasitol. 1989; 33: 13-25Google Scholar, 38Knapp B. Hundt E. Enders B. Kupper H.A. Behring Inst. Mitt. 1991; 88: 147-156Google Scholar). All genes are predicted to possess the four-exon structure characteristic of SERA genes in this and other Plasmodium species with the exception ofSERA8, which is predicted to possess an additional exon and a premature stop codon. All SERA homologues encode a centrally located “papain-like” protease domain, although in SERA1–SERA5 and in SERA9 the active site cysteine residue is present as a serine. RT-PCR analysis was used to determine which members of theSERA multigene family are expressed in parasitized erythrocytes. Initially, cDNA was synthesized by reverse transcription of parasite RNA isolated from an asynchronous culture ofP. falciparum parasites (D10 line) using a poly(dT) primer. This material was subjected to PCR using primers specific for eachSERA gene amplifying across two introns as shown in Fig.1 B. The same primers were also used to amplify the genes from parasite gDNA. Appropriately sized gDNA and cDNA fragments were detected on an ethidium bromide-stained agarose gel (Fig.1 C). Sequencing of these PCR products confirmed the identification of the amplicons and of the intron/exon boundaries. It should be noted that although these fragments were sequenced for correct identification of each gene, rather than to identify polymorphisms, the sequence obtained from the D10 parasite line was almost identical to that published for 3D7 for each gene (24Gardner M.J. Tettelin H. Carucci D.J. Cummings L.M. Aravind L. Koonin E.V. Shallom S. Mason T. Yu K. Fujii C. Pederson J. Shen K. Jing J. Aston C. Lai Z. Schwartz D.C. Pertea M. Salzberg S. Zhou L. Sutton G.G. Clayton R. White O. Smith H.O. Fraser C.M. Hoffman S.L. et al.Science. 1998; 282: 1126-1132Google Scholar). In order to investigate the transcriptional regulation of the chromosome 2 SERA genes, parasite RNA isolated from the same number of synchronized ring, trophozoite, and schizont stage parasites (D10 line) was subjected to RT-PCR as described above. Appropriately sized cDNA fragments representing these eight SERA genes were detected in mature parasites but not in early stage parasites (Fig. 2). The presence ofSERA5 and SERA6 mRNA in mature blood stage forms of the parasite has previously been described (3Li W.B. Bzik D.J. Horii T. Inselburg J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1989; 33: 13-25Google Scholar, 23Knapp B. Nau U. Hundt E. Kupper H.A. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1991; 44: 1-13Google Scholar, 10Fox B.A. Bzik D.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1994; 68: 133-144Google Scholar), consistent with the above results. Although not strictly quantitative, it appears from this experiment that maximal expression for each of the eight chromosome 2 SERA genes occurs in mature parasites. This is in contrast to the expression pattern for the KAHRPcontrol that is transcribed earlier in the parasite life cycle as expected. Note that since the SERA9 gene was not available until relatively recently, it was not included in this experiment. However, in a separate time course experiment, mRNA fromSERA9 appeared to be regulated similarly to the other SERAs (data not shown). To further examine SERA transcription, we used microarray analysis to measure the extent of increase in transcription ofSERA mRNA from young blood stage forms (rings) to mature forms (trophozoites/schizonts). By this analysis, only the centrally located SERA genes in the chromosome 2 cluster, as well asSERA9, showed a significant increase in expression in mature forms (Fig. 3 A). In addition,SERA5 appeared to be substantially more strongly transcribed than other SERA genes. A repeat set of microarray experiments in which the two mRNA samples were labeled with the alternate fluorescent dye revealed almost identical results (Fig.3 B). It should be noted that the microarray datum included here was part of a genome-wide expression analysis that revealed several “hot spots” of mRNA expression increase from young to mature forms. 6R. Crawford K.A. Boley L.J. Landsberg K.E. Gibson H.L. Kaslow D.C. Barr P.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1996; 78: 55-65Google Scholar), P. knowlesi, and several rodent malaria species that we identified by interrogation of Plasmodium sequence data bases (available on the World Wide Web at www.PlasmoDB.org). Six highly conserved blocks were identified, five of which shared ∼45% amino acid identity across the family (Fig. 4). The remaining region (block 5) encompasses the protease-like domain and is even more conserved showing ∼60% identity. In contrast, a number of highly variable regions were identified, the most divergent of which is at the N terminus (Fig. 4, solid line). For 40 million years, diatoms have dominated the reverse weathering of silica on Earth. These photosynthetic protists take up dissolved silicic acid from the water and precipitate opaline silica to form their cell wall. We show that the biosilica of diatoms is an effective pH buffer, enabling the enzymatic conversion of bicarbonate to CO2, an important step in inorganic carbon acquisition by these organisms. Because diatoms are responsible for one-quarter of global primary production and for a large fraction of the carbon exported to the deep sea, the global cycles of Si and C may be linked mechanistically.

Vanilloid receptor 1 (VR1), a ligand-gated ion channel activated by vanilloids, acid, and heat, is a molecular detector that integrates multiple modes of pain. Although the function and the biophysical properties of the channel are now known, the regions of VR1 that recognize ligands are largely unknown. By the stepwise deletion of VR1 and by chimera construction using its capsaicin-insensitive homologue, VRL1, we localized key amino acids, Arg-114 and Glu-761, in the N- and C-cytosolic tails, respectively, that determine ligand binding. Point mutations of the two key residues resulted in a loss of sensitivity to capsaicin and a concomitant loss of specific binding to [3H]resiniferatoxin, a potent vanilloid. Furthermore, changes in the charges of the two amino acids blocked capsaicin-sensitive currents and ligand binding without affecting current responses to heat. Thus, these two regions in the cytoplasmic tails of VR1 provide structural elements for its hydrophilic interaction with vanilloids and might constitute a long-suspected binding pocket. Vanilloid receptor 1 (VR1), a ligand-gated ion channel activated by vanilloids, acid, and heat, is a molecular detector that integrates multiple modes of pain. Although the function and the biophysical properties of the channel are now known, the regions of VR1 that recognize ligands are largely unknown. By the stepwise deletion of VR1 and by chimera construction using its capsaicin-insensitive homologue, VRL1, we localized key amino acids, Arg-114 and Glu-761, in the N- and C-cytosolic tails, respectively, that determine ligand binding. Point mutations of the two key residues resulted in a loss of sensitivity to capsaicin and a concomitant loss of specific binding to [3H]resiniferatoxin, a potent vanilloid. Furthermore, changes in the charges of the two amino acids blocked capsaicin-sensitive currents and ligand binding without affecting current responses to heat. Thus, these two regions in the cytoplasmic tails of VR1 provide structural elements for its hydrophilic interaction with vanilloids and might constitute a long-suspected binding pocket.
