The reaction products were separated by SDS-PAGE and transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane, and the C-terminal peptide of NSP generated by proteolytic cleavage was subjected to Edman degradation analysis. To ensure that the observed transient stability of t-PA·NSP acyl-enzyme complexes was a true reflection of the protein properties and not a function of an SDS-PAGE-based assay (29Gaussem P. Grailhe P. Angles-Cano E. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 12150-12155Google Scholar, 30Gils A. Declerck P.J. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1998; 80: 286-291Google Scholar), a chromogenic substrate-based assay of t-PA enzymatic activity was used. Equimolar amounts of NSP and t-PA were incubated for increasing times, t-PA enzymatic activity was monitored via cleavage of chromogenic substrate (Fig. 5, A and B), and aliquots of the same reactions were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and Western blotting to determine the fate of the NSP (Fig. 5, Cand D). Fig. 5 demonstrates that with increasing time, the enzymatic activity of t-PA that had been inhibited by NSP was recovered (Fig. 5, A and B, enzymatic activity), concomitant with the generation of cleaved NSP (Fig. 5, Cand D; the appearance of the 40-kDa cleavage product demonstrating deacylation had occurred). Control experiments with t-PA inhibition by PAI-1 (Fig. 5, A and B) yielded no recovery of enzymatic activity of either form of t-PA subsequent to their interaction with PAI-1. Hence, the transient stability of t-PA·NSP acyl-enzyme complexes is a property of the reactants and is not a function of the assay. In addition, these data demonstrate that functional t-PA is recovered with deacylation of t-PA·NSP complexes. Figs. 2 and 5 also demonstrate that NSP cleavage by either form of t-PA proceeds via the transient acyl-enzyme intermediate, with little evidence for a NSP population that acts as a pure t-PA substrate. Slowing the reaction by carrying it out at 4 °C revealed that cleaved NSP was preceded by the appearance of acyl-enzyme complexes (Fig. 6). Hence, even under conditions that favor substrate behavior by serpins (lowering the reaction temperature fosters the substrate behavior of serpins due to slowing of protease translocation, a temperature-sensitive process, with little influence on deacylation) (31Kjoller L. Martensen P.M. Sottrup-Jensen L. Justesen J. Rodenburg K.W. Andreasen P.A. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 241: 38-46Google Scholar), all NSP proceeds to cleavage via the acyl-enzyme intermediate. In addition, all of the NSP is eventually cleaved, without evidence of a latent form of the serpin (Fig. 2 for tct-PA, not shown for sct-PA). Therefore, NSP appears to act as a single population of molecules that is cleaved by t-PA via transition through a detectable acyl-enzyme intermediate. The data presented thus far suggest that the interactions between NSP and t-PA are more similar to cleavage of a substrate with a protracted intermediate than the biologically irreversible inhibition usually associated with serpins. If this is the case, inclusion of NSP in an assay that measures t-PA enzymatic activity over a time period that allows deacylation to occur should yield a pattern more similar to that of a substrate than to the pattern seen with PAI-1. To test this hypothesis, the inhibition profiles of sct-PA- and tct-PA-mediated125I-plasminogen cleavage by PAI-1, NSP, and a physiologic substrate, unlabeled plasminogen, were compared. The NSP inhibition profiles of both forms of t-PA are very similar to the profiles of inhibition by a competitive substrate, unlabeled plasminogen, and differ from the inhibition profiles of PAI-1 (Fig.7). This difference is unlikely to be due solely to differences in affinities of t-PA for PAI-1 versusNSP, as the time to onset and extent of maximal protease inhibition by PAI-1 and NSP appeared to be similar in the chromogenic substrate-based assays detailed in Fig. 5. It seems that NSP is neither a pure inhibitor nor a pure substrate of t-PA, as the rate of NSP-t-PA acyl-enzyme complex deacylation in vitro is rapid enough to make inhibition transient, at best, but slow enough to constitute a significant kinetic stutter step in the substrate behavior of NSP and therefore to interrupt proteolysis of an alternative substrate by t-PA. Such an interpretation is consistent with the protective effects seen with transgene-driven overexpression of NSP or with the administration of pharmacological concentrations of NSP into the central nervous system of mice with middle cerebral artery occlusion (13Yepes M. Sandkvist M. Wong M.K. Coleman T.A. Smith E. Cohan S.L. Lawrence D.A. Blood. 2000; 96: 569-576Google Scholar, 16Lawrence D.A. Ginsburg D. Day D.E. Berkenpas M.B. Verhamme I.M. Kvassman J.O. Shore J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 25309-25312Google Scholar). Another aspect to be considered is the effect of plasmin on NSP-sensitive processes. If t-PA effect in the central nervous system is plasminogen-dependent, as much data suggest (32Chen Z.L. Strickland S. Cell. 1997; 91: 917-925Google Scholar), the rapid and efficient cleavage of NSP by plasmin will have to be considered and balanced against the blunting of plasmin generation by NSP. Likewise, if NSP is ultimately cleaved by both t-PA and plasmin, a potential but heretofore unknown function for cleaved NSP may be part of the process. According to its predicted structure, NSP bears a series of negatively charged residues in an alignment similar to the positively charged residues on the face of the D-helix in certain serpins that bind heparin with resultant augmented inhibitory activity (33Osterwalder T. Contartese J. Stoeckli E.T. Kuhn T.B. Sonderegger P. EMBO. 1996; 15: 2944-2953Google Scholar). As such, there is the possibility that a positively charged cofactor binds NSP and augments or stabilizes its inhibitory activity. Such a cofactor was sought by combining NSP with homogenates of mouse hippocampus to allow for interaction between NSP and a potential cofactor, followed by the addition of t-PA. There was no evidence of improved efficiency of t-PA inhibition or of stabilization of t-PA·NSP complexes (data not shown). The data presented above raise intriguing questions about the nature of the physiologic interaction between t-PA and NSP. In processes involving other protease-serpin pairs, the acyl-enzyme complex presents molecular determinants not present on the individual reactants that allow cellular internalization of the complex, classically via the LDL receptor-related protein molecule (17Higazi A.A. Upson R.H. Cohen R.L. Manuppello J. Bognacki J. Henkin J. McCrae K.R. Kounnas M.Z. Strickland D.K. Preissner K.T. Lawler J. Cines D.B. Blood. 1996; 88: 542-551Google Scholar). The time required for complex internalization in in vitroexperiments (34Zhang J.-C. Sakthivel R. Kniss D. Grahm C.H. Strickland D.K. McCrae K.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 32273-32280Google Scholar) suggests that this process may not be rapid enough to clear t-PA·NSP complexes before deacylation at 37 °C. Hence, it will be of interest to determine whether t-PA·NSP acyl-enzyme complexes have a different fate than do other protease-serpin pairs. Alternatively, given that sct-PA·NSP complexes are longer lived than tct-PA·NSP complexes, NSP may serve to selectively inactivate or mediate clearance of sct-PA. At present, however, these remain speculations to be tested experimentally. Given that stable acyl-enzyme complexes are characteristic of cognate protease-serpin pairs, with relatively unstable complexes being observed in some noncognate pairs (35Plotnick M.I. Sandkur M. Wang Z.M. Liu X. Rubin H. Schechter N.M. Selwood T. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 334-342Google Scholar), it seems reasonable to examine whether NSP is indeed a physiologic inhibitor of t-PA. Relating the data in statement (i) that families with a point mutation of NSP, resulting in in situ polymerization of NSP and presumably a decrease in soluble NSP, manifest their first clinical signs of disease as spontaneous seizures (36Takao M. Benson M. Murrell J. Yazaki M. Piccardo P. Unverzagt F. Davis R. Holohon P. Laurence D. Richardson R. Fralow M. Ghetti B. J. Neuropathol. Exp. Neurol. 2000; 59: 1070-1086Google Scholar), and the data in statement (ii) rodent models demonstrate t-PA-dependent propagation of seizures that is blocked by NSP (37Yepes M. Sandkust M. Coleman T.A. Moore E. Wu J.Y. Mitola D. Bugge T.H. Lawrence D.A. J. Clin. Invest. 2002; 109: 1571-1578Google Scholar), it seems likely that a t-PA-NSP interaction takes place in vivo as a part of seizure-prevention processes. It will therefore be important to reconcile the observed biochemical characteristics of NSP with observations on its in vivo actions. We thank Henriette Remmer and Karen Avenatti from the Protein Sciences Facility, University of Illinois for assistance in N-terminal peptide sequence analysis. We would also like to thank Richard Guerra for work on the interactions between urokinase and NSP and Debora McCall for help and expertise in preparation of this manuscript.

Recently, our laboratory reported an intricate regulation of the human reduced folate carrier (hRFC) gene, involving multiple promoters and noncoding exons. We localized promoter activity to a 452-bp GC-rich region upstream of noncoding exon A, including a 47-bp basal promoter with a CRE/AP-1-like consensus element that bound the bZip family of DNA-binding proteins (e.g.CREB-1 and c-Jun). We now report that three nearly identical tandem repeats (49–61 bp) in the hRFC-A upstream region are involved in regulating promoter activity. By in vitro binding assays, multiple transcription factors (e.g. AP2 and Sp1/Sp3) bound this region. When AP2 was cotransfected with the hRFC-A reporter construct into HT1080 cells, promoter activity increased 3-fold. In Drosophila SL2 cells, Sp1 transactivated promoter A and showed synergism with CREB-1. However, c-Jun was antagonistic to the effects of Sp1. A sequence variant in the hRFC-A repeated region was identified, involving an exact duplication of a 61-bp sequence. This variant had an allelic frequency of 78% in 72 genomic DNAs and resulted in a 63% increase in promoter activity. These results identify important regions in the hRFC-A promoter and critical roles for AP2 and Sp1, in combination with the bZip transcription factors. Moreover, they document a functionally novel polymorphism that increases promoter activity and may contribute to interpatient variations in hRFC expression and effects on tissue folate homeostasis and antitumor response to antifolates.

To understand molecular pathways underlying 9p21 deletions, which lead to inactivation of the p16/CDKN2A, p14/ARF, and/or p15/CDKN2B genes, in lymphoid leukemia, 30 breakpoints were cloned from 15 lymphoid leukemia cell lines. Seventeen (57%) breakpoints were mapped at five breakpoint cluster sites, BCS-LL1 to LL5, each of <15 bp. Two breakpoint cluster sites were located within the ARF and CDKN2Bloci, respectively, whereas the remaining three were located >100 kb distal to the CDKN2A, ARF, andCDKN2B loci. The sequences of breakpoint junctions indicated that deletions in the 11 (73%) cell lines were mediated by illegitimate V(D)J recombination targeted at the five BCS-LL and six other sites, which contain sequences similar to recombination signal sequences for V(D)J recombination. An extrachromosomal V(D)J recombination assay indicated that BCS-LL3, at which the largest number of breakpoints (i.e. five breakpoints) was clustered, has a V(D)J recombination potential 150-fold less than the consensus recombination signal sequence. Three other BCS-LLs tested also showed V(D)J recombination potential, although it was lower than that of BCS-LL3. These results indicated that illegitimate V(D)J recombination, which was targeted at several ectopic recombination signal sequences widely distributed in 9p21, caused a large fraction of 9p21 deletions in lymphoid leukemia. V(D)J recombination is a physiological recombination of DNAs, which occurs at the Ig and T cell receptor loci during the differentiation of lymphoid cells (1Lewis S.M. Adv. Immunol. 1994; 56: 27-150Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Fugmann S.D. Lee A.I. Shockett P.E. Villey I.J. Schatz D.G. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2000; 18: 495-527Crossref PubMed Scopus (496) Google Scholar). These loci have recombination signal sequences (RSSs) 1The abbreviations used for: RSS, recombination signal sequence; RAG, recombination-activating gene; DSB, DNA double strand break; T-ALL, T cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia; STS, sequence-tagged site. 1The abbreviations used for: RSS, recombination signal sequence; RAG, recombination-activating gene; DSB, DNA double strand break; T-ALL, T cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia; STS, sequence-tagged site.consisting of a highly conserved heptamer sequence (consensus 5′-CACAGTG) and an AT-rich nonamer sequence (consensus 5′-ACAAAAACC). The recombination-activating gene (RAG) complex generates DNA double strand breaks (DSBs) at pairs of RSSs in which one signal has a 12-bp spacer between the heptamer and nonamer (12-signal) and the other signal has a 23-bp spacer (23-signal) (1Lewis S.M. Adv. Immunol. 1994; 56: 27-150Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Fugmann S.D. Lee A.I. Shockett P.E. Villey I.J. Schatz D.G. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2000; 18: 495-527Crossref PubMed Scopus (496) Google Scholar). This is known as the 12/23 rule. Several nucleotides are inserted as junctional additions at the junctions, and the broken DNA ends are rejoined by the nonhomologous end joining pathway (1Lewis S.M. Adv. Immunol. 1994; 56: 27-150Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Fugmann S.D. Lee A.I. Shockett P.E. Villey I.J. Schatz D.G. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2000; 18: 495-527Crossref PubMed Scopus (496) Google Scholar, 3Lieber M.R. Am. J. Pathol. 1998; 153: 1323-1332Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar). The results of V(D)J recombination are that coding junction products and, in some cases such as the Ig κ locus, signal junction products are left in the human genomic DNA (1Lewis S.M. Adv. Immunol. 1994; 56: 27-150Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). It has been suggested that recurrent chromosomal aberrations in lymphoid malignancies, such as translocations and inversions involving the Ig and T cell receptor loci, are caused by illegitimate actions of the V(D)J recombination machinery at “ectopic” RSSs, the sequences homologous to the consensus RSS at non-Ig, non-T cell receptor loci (4Croce C.M. Cell. 1987; 49: 155-156Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar, 5Korsmeyer S.J. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1992; 10: 785-807Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 6Rabbitts T.H. Willerford D.M. Blood. 1999; 94: 3997-4010Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Davila M. Foster S. Kelsoe G. Yang K. Adv. Cancer Res. 2001; 81: 61-92Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). These chromosomal aberrations cause the activation or fusion of several oncogenes leading to leukemogenesis. In a large portion of these aberrations, insertions of nucleotides were detected between the two joined germ line sequences. In addition, recently, several DNA fragments containing the ectopic RSSs were shown to have potential to undergo V(D)J recombinationin vivo (10Lewis S.M. Agard E. Suh S. Czyzyk L. Mol. Cell. Thus, it was indicated that illegitimate V(D)J recombination is a major cause for the occurrence of these chromosomal aberrations.Deletion of the chromosome 9p21 region is a crucial event for the development of lymphoid leukemia irrespective of lineages, since homozygous deletions of this region have been found in 20–50% of lymphoid leukemia both of T- and B-lineages (13Ohnishi H. Kawamura M. Ida K. Sheng X.M. Hanada R. Nobori T. Yamamori S. Hayashi Y. Blood. 1995; 86: 1269-1275Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 14Drexler H.G. Leukemia. 1998; 12: 845-859Crossref PubMed Scopus (371) Google Scholar). The chromosome 9p21 segment contains the 40-kb region encoding thep16/CDKN2A tumor suppressor gene and two other related genes, p14/ARF andp15/CDKN2B, all of which encode critical factors for the regulation of cell cycle and/or apoptosis (15Kohno T. Yokota J. Carcinogenesis. 1999; 20: 1403-1410Crossref PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar, 16Sherr C.J. Cancer Res. 2000; 60: 3689-3695PubMed Google Scholar). Previously, Cayuela et al. (17Cayuela J.M. Gardie B. Sigaux F. Blood. 1997; 90: 3720-3726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) characterized three sites of breakpoint clustering in T cell acute lymphoblastic leukemias (T-ALLs) in the 40-kb region. The three sites consisted of a major breakpoint cluster site, MTS1bcrβ, and two minor sites, MTS1bcrα and MTS2bcr1 (see Fig. 1 A). All three sites contained heptamer-RSS-like sequences; therefore, it was suggested that illegitimate V(D)J recombination is involved in the occurrence of 9p21 deletions in T-ALL. However, in that study, structures of only a small number of breakpoint-containing regions in leukemia cells only of T-lineage were analyzed. In addition, the involvement of V(D)J recombination was suggested only by the sequences of breakpoints and was not functionally assessed. Therefore, it still remains largely obscure whether illegitimate V(D)J recombination is a major cause for 9p21 deletions in lymphoid leukemia.In the present study, 30 breakpoints for 9p21 deletions were cloned in 15 human lymphoid leukemia cell lines consisting of nine T- and six B-lineage lines. The breakpoints were distributed at 18 different sites in the 9p21 segment. Seventeen (57%) of the breakpoints were mapped at five breakpoint cluster sites, BCS-LL1 to LL5, each of <15-bp. One of the breakpoint cluster sites, BCS-LL2, was the same as MTS1bcrβ (17Cayuela J.M. Gardie B. Sigaux F. Blood. 1997; 90: 3720-3726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), whereas the remaining four sites were novel. Two breakpoint clustering sites were located within the 40-kb region encoding the CDKN2A, ARF, and CDKN2Bgenes, whereas the remaining three were located >100 kb apart from the 40-kb region. Thus, the results further supported the previous finding of breakpoint clustering for 9p21 deletions in lymphoid leukemia. All five BCS-LLs and seven other breakpoint sites contained the CAC trinucleotide, which is identical to the first three nucleotides of heptamer-RSSs indispensable for V(D)J recombination. The sequences of breakpoint junctions indicated that deletions in the majority (11 lines, 73%) of the cell lines were mediated by illegitimate V(D)J recombination preferentially targeted at BCS-LLs, and such a recombination occurred in both the T- and B-lineage cell lines. Thus, we further performed an extrachromosomal V(D)J recombination assay to functionally assess the V(D)J recombination potential of BCS-LLs. All of the four BCS-LL fragments tested were shown to have the potential to undergo V(D)J recombination as RSSs, whereas the efficiency and specificity of the potential were different among the fragments. The present results strongly indicated that illegitimate V(D)J recombination, which was targeted at RSS-like sequences widely distributed in the 9p21 segment, causes a major (>70%) fraction of 9p21 deletions in lymphoid leukemia of both T- and B-lineages. There was no evidence of V(D)J recombination at the breakpoint junctions of the remaining four (27%) cell lines, raising the possibility that 9p21 deletions in a small subset of lymphoid leukemia were caused by mechanisms other than illegitimate V(D)J recombination.DISCUSSIONIn the present study, the distribution of 33 breakpoints for 9p21 deletions in 21 lymphoid leukemia were examined in the 240-kb segment covering the 40-kb region containing the CDKN2A,ARF, and CDKN2B loci, the region where the breakpoint distribution was previously examined in T-ALL (17Cayuela J.M. Gardie B. Sigaux F. Blood. 1997; 90: 3720-3726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). This breakpoint mapping and the subsequent breakpoint cloning enabled us to identify three breakpoint cluster sites, BCS-LL1 to LL3. These three sites contained four or five breakpoints; thus, they were considered as major breakpoint cluster sites (Fig. 2, A and B). BCS-LL2 was the same as MTS1bcrβ in the ARF locus, where the significant portion (>60%) of the breakpoints in T-ALL had been previously mapped; therefore, the result of Cayuela et al.(17Cayuela J.M. Gardie B. Sigaux F. Blood. 1997; 90: 3720-3726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) was confirmed. In the present study, an additional major breakpoint cluster site, BCS-LL3, was identified in theCDKN2B locus, and another site, BCS-LL1, was identified in the MTAP locus of >100 kb distal to the CDKN2A,ARF, and CDKN2B loci (Fig. 2 A). Furthermore, two additional breakpoint cluster sites, BCS-LL4 and -LL5, were also identified at loci >100 kb distal to these loci (Fig.2 A). Since two or three breakpoints among those identified by us or Cayuela et al. (17Cayuela J.M. Gardie B. Sigaux F. Blood. 1997; 90: 3720-3726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) were located at these sites, they were considered as being minor breakpoint cluster sites. Cayuelaet al. (17Cayuela J.M. Gardie B. Sigaux F. Blood. 1997; 90: 3720-3726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) also identified two minor breakpoint cluster sites, MTS1bcrα and MTS2bcr1, in the vicinity of theCDKN2A and CDKN2B loci, respectively (Fig.2 A). However, none of the breakpoints in this study were mapped at these two sites. Therefore, they are likely to be minor cluster sites as previously reported (17Cayuela J.M. Gardie B. Sigaux F. Blood. 1997; 90: 3720-3726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, the present result further supported the previous finding that breakpoints for 9p21 deletions in lymphoid leukemia are clustered. In addition, it was found that both the breakpoints of T- and B-lineage cell lines were located at the BCS-LL sites. Thus, the present result also indicates that the breakpoint cluster sites are susceptible to DNA breaks during lymphoid leukemogenesis irrespective of cell lineages.All BCS-LLs contained the CAC trinucleotide, which is identical to the first three nucleotides of heptamer-RSSs indispensable for V(D)J recombination. In addition, 7 of the 13 sites, where a single breakpoint was mapped in this study, also contained the CAC trinucleotide within 23 bp of each breakpoint. Therefore, in total, 12 (67%) of the 18 sites contained the CAC trinucleotide (Fig. 1). Since the probability of finding CAC in the genome is 1 in 64 bp (¼ × ¼ × ¼ = 1/64), 18 sites of 23-bp, each of which contains 21 trinucleotides, could contain six copies of CAC (18 × 21 × 1/64 = 5.9). Therefore, the CAC trinucleotide was overrepresented at the breakpoints. Breakpoint junctions in 11 (73.3%) cell lines consisting of seven T- and four B-lineage lines showed typical evidence of V(D)J recombination (Fig.3 A). The CAC trinucleotide, which flanked both the distal and proximal breakpoints, was deleted with the segment encoding theCDKN2A, ARF, and CDKN2B genes, and nucleotides of 1–10 bp were inserted at the breakpoint junctions. The deletions in these cases were typical of coding junctions of V(D)J recombination. DSBs generated by the RAG complex are processed to the P-nucleotide and/or N-nucleotide additions in the case of coding junctions (1Lewis S.M. Adv. Immunol. 1994; 56: 27-150Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Three of the 22 breakpoints in these 11 cases, distal ones of L-SMY and CCRF-CEM and a proximal one of KOPT-K1, were located next to the CAC trinucleotide, respectively, and one or two nucleotides complementary to the germ line sequences upstream of the CAC trinucleotide were inserted at the junctions (underlined in Fig. 3 A). These nucleotides are likely to be P-nucleotides. The remaining 19 breakpoints were located 1–15 bp away from the heptamer-RSS-like sequences; therefore, inserted N-nucleotides (rather than P-nucleotides) probably account for nucleotide sequences beside those breakpoints. Thus, overrepresentation of CAC in the vicinity of breakpoints as well as the sequences of the breakpoint junctions indicated that the majority (>70%) of 9p21 deletions in lymphoid leukemia of both T- and B-lineages are caused by illegitimate V(D)J recombination.In the remaining four (27%) cell lines, V(D)J recombination was not evident at the breakpoint junctions (Fig. 3 B). In two T-lineage cell lines, P12/Ichikawa and KAWAI, only proximal breakpoints were flanked by the CAC trinucleotide, and nucleotides were not inserted at the junctions. In two B-lineage cell lines, HPB-NULL and THP-7, breakpoints were not flanked by the CAC trinucleotide. Therefore, it was likely that deletions in these cell lines were generated by mechanisms other than illegitimate V(D)J recombination. Joining of nonhomologous DNA without evidence of V(D)J recombination has been detected at the breakpoint junctions for the interstitial deletions in nonhematological malignancies, including 9p21 deletions in two cases of glioma (30Canning S. Dryja T.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 5044-5048Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar, 31Pomykala H.M. Bohlander S.K. Broeker P.L. Olopade O.I. Diaz M.O. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 7604-7610Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar, 32Kohno T. Otsuka T. Inazawa J. Abe T. Yokota J. DNA Res. 1996; 3: 421-424Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar, 33Nishioka M. Kohno T. Takahashi M. Niki T. Yamada T. Sone S. Yokota J. Oncogene. 2001; 19: 6251-6260Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar). Therefore, as hypothesized in nonhematological malignancies (3Lieber M.R. Am. J. Pathol. 1998; 153: 1323-1332Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar, 34Chen C. Kolodner R.D. Nat. Genet. 1999; 23: 81-85Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 35Jasin M. Cancer Invest. 2000; 18: 78-86Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar), 9p21 deletions in a subset of lymphoid leukemias, such as these four cell lines, may have also been generated by nonhomologous end joining of DSBs caused by unknown mechanisms. Meanwhile, the proximal breakpoint of P12/Ichikawa was located at BCS-LL2. Therefore, it might be that the DSB at the proximal breakpoint in this cell line was generated by the illegitimate action of the RAG complex. The broken DNA ends generated by the RAG complex may have rejoined with other broken ends generated by other mechanisms.Notably, in 10 of the 11 cell lines whose 9p21 deletions were possibly caused by illegitimate V(D)J recombination, one or both of the proximal and distal breakpoints were located at BCS-LLs. However, the RSS-like sequences, even those at BCS-LLs, showed only a partial homology to the consensus RSSs (Fig. 2 B, Table I). Thus, we assessed the V(D)J recombination potential of DNA fragments containing the RSS-like sequences. We subjected four BCS-LL fragments, BCS-LL1, -LL2, -LL3, and -LL5, to the extrachromosomal V(D)J recombination assay in Reh cells with V(D)J recombination activity (29Gauss G.H. Domain I. Hsieh C.L. Lieber M.R. Eur. J. Immunol. 1998; 28: 351-358Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). The BCS-LL3 fragment positioned as a 12-signal (i.e. pLL3-RSS) showed the highest recombination frequency (Table II), indicating that this fragment had the highest recombination potential among the four fragments tested. This result was consistent with the fact that the largest portions (i.e. five breakpoints) of the breakpoints were clustered at BCS-LL3 (Fig. 2 A). Other cluster sites, BCS-LL1 and BCS-LL5, that were located >100-kb apart from the CDKN2A,ARF, and CDKN2B loci, were also shown to undergo V(D)J recombination as RSSs, respectively. It was inferred that BCS-LL2 has a V(D)J recombination potential both as 12- and 23-signals, but its potential, especially as a 23-signal, was considerably lower than other BCS-LL fragments. This result was contrary to the fact that a considerable number of breakpoints were clustered at the BCS-LL2 site in this (Fig. 2 B) and a previous studies (17Cayuela J.M. Gardie B. Sigaux F. Blood. 1997; 90: 3720-3726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). BCS-LL2 is located in a CA/GT tract, and this tract was not cloned into the pLL2-RSS and pRSS-LL2 plasmids (Table I). CA/GT tracts are speculated to adopt the Z-DNA structure (17Cayuela J.M. Gardie B. Sigaux F. Blood. 1997; 90: 3720-3726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), which might enhance V(D)J recombination; thus, the recombination potential of BCS-LL2 could be enhanced by the CA/GT tract.In the present study, all four BCS-LL fragments tested showed potential as RSSs, although the efficiency and specificity as RSS were different among the fragments. Especially, the estimated V(D)J recombination potential of BCS-LL1 and -LL3, two major cluster sites, were similar to that of other ectopic RSSs, which have been predicted to pair with physiological RSSs to give rise to recurrent translocations in lymphoid leukemia (11Raghavan S.C. Kirsch I.R. Lieber M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 29126-29133Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). In the 9p21 deletions analyzed in this study, the BCS-LL3 site was joined with the BCS-LL1 site, but not with the BCS-LL5 site, to give rise to deletions (Fig. 3 A). This is consistent with the fact that the BCS-LL3 and BCS-LL5 sites preferentially acted as 12-signals, whereas the BCS-LL1 site acted as a 23-signal. The BCS-LL5 site with a 12-signal potential was joined with the BCS-LL2 site, for which a weak potential as a 23-signal was suggested (Fig. 3 A). Thus, it is likely that the occurrence of 9p21 deletions conformed to the 12/23 rule (1Lewis S.M. Adv. Immunol. 1994; 56: 27-150Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Fugmann S.D. Lee A.I. Shockett P.E. Villey I.J. Schatz D.G. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2000; 18: 495-527Crossref PubMed Scopus (496) Google Scholar). V(D)J recombination by pairing of two ectopic RSSs, BCS-LL1 and BCS-LL3, was not recapitulated in the extrachromosomal recombination assay; however, this was conceivable, since its predicted recombination frequency was too low to be detected by this system (11Raghavan S.C. Kirsch I.R. Lieber M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 29126-29133Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). Thus, the present results strongly support the fact that illegitimate V(D)J recombination, targeted at ectopic RSSs in 9p21, causes a large fraction of 9p21 deletions in lymphoid leukemia.The majority of the breakpoints were clustered at BCS-LLs despite the fact that the 9p21 segment analyzed in this study contained thousands of CAC trinucleotides. Thus, it is possible that BCS-LLs have specific structures enhancing V(D)J recombination other than the CAC trinucleotide. It is noted that BCS-LL1, -LL3, and -LL5 specifically functioned as a 12- or 23-signal contrary to the fact that they have no obvious nonamer-RSS-like sequences (Table I). In addition, the recombination potential of BCS-LLs was not correlated to the degrees of their homologies with the consensus RSSs. These results indicate that BCS-LL fragments can take specific configurations as RSSs, irrespective of their homologies with the consensus RSSs. In addition, it is also noted that all of the five BCS-LLs were located in, or upstream of, the genes in this region (Fig. 2 A). The MTAP andCDKN2A genes are expressed ubiquitously in a variety of human tissues, including hematopoietic progenitor cells (20Nobori T. Takabayashi K. Tran P. Orvis L. Batova A. Yu A.L. Carson D.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 6203-6208Crossref PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar, 36Yu J. Batova A. Shao L. Carrera C.J.A.L. Yu A.L. Clin. Recent studies have indicated that the open chromatin structure associated with gene expression is a critical factor determining the efficiency of V(D)J recombination, probably changing the accessibility of the V(D)J recombination machinery (38Cherry S.R. Baltimore D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 10788-10793Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar, 39Kwon J. Morshead K.B. Guyon J.R. Kingston R.E. Oettinger M.A. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1037-1048Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar). Therefore, the local chromatin structure of BCS-LLs might further enhance the susceptibility to illegitimate V(D)J recombination. Illegitimate V(D)J recombination has been indicated as being involved in a variety of chromosomal aberrations in lymphoid leukemias (8Vanasse G.J. Concannon P. Willerford D.M. Blood. 1999; 94: 3997-4010Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Davila M. Foster S. Kelsoe G. Yang K. Adv. Cancer Res. 2001; 81: 61-92Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). However, only a few candidate ectopic RSSs have been functionally assessed for their potential as RSSs (10Lewis S.M. Agard E. Suh S. Czyzyk L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1997; 17: 3125-3136Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar, 11Raghavan S.C. Kirsch I.R. Lieber M.R. J. Biol. Thus, genomic structures underlying illegitimate V(D)J recombination should be further investigated to define the mechanisms underlying 9p21 deletions and other recurrent chromosomal aberrations that occur in lymphoid leukemogenesis. We sought to characterize the role of upstream kinases in the regulation of the MAP3 kinase MEKK1 and the potential impact on signaling to MAP kinase cascades. We find that the MAP4 kinase PAK1 phosphorylates the amino terminus of MEKK1 on serine 67. We show that serine 67 lies in a D domain, which binds to the c-Jun-NH2-terminal kinase/stress-activated protein kinases (JNK/SAPK). Serine 67 is constitutively phosphorylated in resting 293 cells, but is dephosphorylated following exposure to stress stimuli such as anisomycin and UV irradiation. Phosphorylation of this site inhibits binding of JNK/SAPK to MEKK1. Thus, we propose a mechanism by which the MEKK1-dependent JNK/SAPK pathway is negatively regulated by PAK through phosphorylation of serine 67. Phosphorylation of this site inhibits binding of JNK/SAPK to MEKK1. Thus, we propose a mechanism by which the MEKK1-dependent JNK/SAPK pathway is negatively regulated by PAK through phosphorylation of serine 67. MAP 1The abbreviations used for: MAP, mitogen-activated protein; ERK, extracellular signal-regulated kinase; MEK, mitogen-activated protein kinase/extracellular signal-regulated kinase kinase; MEKK, MEK kinase; PAK, p21-activated kinase; JNK, c-Jun-NH2-terminal kinase; SAPK, stress-activated protein kinase; TNF, tumor necrosis factor; IL, interleukin; MALDI-TOF, matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight; PP2A, phosphoprotein phosphatase 2A; PKA, protein kinase A; EGF, epidermal growth factor; GST, glutathioneS-transferase. kinase cascades are ubiquitous signal transduction pathways that regulate a wide array of cellular functions and processes (1Chen Z. Gibson T.B. Robinson F. Silvestro L. Pearson G. Xu Be B.E. Wright A. Vanderbilt C. Cobb M.H. Chem. Rev. 2001; 101: 2449-2476Crossref PubMed Scopus (794) Google Scholar). The prototypical MAP kinase pathway controls the pheromone-induced mating response of budding yeast. Genes whose loss of function prevented mating were termed sterile (Ste) genes (2Elion E.A. Curr. Opin. Microbiol. 2000; 3: 573-581Crossref PubMed Scopus (225) Google Scholar). The proteins encoded by these genes include protein kinases forming a MAP kinase cascade; Ste20p (MAP4 kinase), Ste11p (MAP3 kinase), and Ste7p (MAP2 kinase) work in series to phosphorylate and activate the MAP kinases Kss1p and Fus3p. The kinases are assembled on the scaffold Ste5p and its associated molecules. Ten years ago, purification of the MAP kinase ERK1 and the MAP2 kinase known as MEK1 or MKK1 led to the isolation of their cDNAs, revealing that mammalian cells contained homologous cascades. At that time a search began for mammalian counterparts of the more upstream components of the cascade, using the sequences of the yeast proteins. The first of these efforts led to the isolation of the Ste11p homolog MEKK1 (3Lange-Carter C.A. Pleiman C.M. Gardner A.M. Blumer K.J. Johnson G.L. Science. 1993; 260: 315-319Crossref PubMed Scopus (875) Google Scholar). Subsequently the p21-activated kinases (PAKs) were recognized as Ste20p homologs, and a plethora of other Ste11p and Ste20p homologs were identified (4Manser E. Leung T. Salihuddin H. Zhao Z.-S. Lim L. Nature. 1994; 367: 40-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (1305) Google Scholar, 5Fanger G.R. Gerwins P. Widmann C. Jarpe M.B. Johnson G.L. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1997; 7: 67-74Crossref PubMed Scopus (299) Google Scholar, 6Widmann C. Gibson S. Jarpe M.B. Johnson G.L. Physiol. Rev. 1999; 79: 143-180Crossref PubMed Scopus (2292) Google Scholar, 7Dan I. Watanabe N.M. Kusumi A. Trends Cell Biol. 2001; 11: 220-230Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (514) Google Scholar). More than a dozen MAP kinases have now been found in metazoans, most known to be regulated by similar kinase cascades (1Chen Z. Gibson T.B. Robinson F. Silvestro L. Pearson G. Xu Be B.E. Wright A. Vanderbilt C. Cobb M.H. Chem. Rev. 2001; 101: 2449-2476Crossref PubMed Scopus (794) Google Scholar). The c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase/stress-activated protein kinase (JNK/SAPK) MAP kinase pathway participates in many stress responses, such as those induced by hypoxia, cold shock, and hyperosmolarity (6Widmann C. Gibson S. Jarpe M.B. Johnson G.L. Physiol. Rev. 1999; 79: 143-180Crossref PubMed Scopus (2292) Google Scholar, 8Davis R.J. Cell. 2000; 103: 239-252Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3666) Google Scholar). There are three genes encoding JNK/SAPKs in mammals; many JNK/SAPK protein species are generated through alternate splicing. The MAP2 kinases in the JNK/SAPK cascade are MKK4 and MKK7 (also known as MEK4 and MEK7). Several MAP3 kinases have been implicated in regulating this cascade including MEKK1, MLK2, ASK1, and TAK1 (5Fanger G.R. Gerwins P. Widmann C. Jarpe M.B. Johnson G.L. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1997; 7: 67-74Crossref PubMed Scopus (299) Google Scholar, 6Widmann C. Gibson S. Jarpe M.B. Johnson G.L. Physiol. Rev. 1999; 79: 143-180Crossref PubMed Scopus (2292) Google Scholar, 8Davis R.J. Cell. 2000; 103: 239-252Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3666) Google Scholar). The relationship between these MAP3 kinases and cellular stimuli that activate JNK/SAPK remain vague. MEKK1 binds directly to JNK/SAPK, suggesting that it is a significant regulator of the pathway (9Xu S. Cobb M.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 32056-32060Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar, 10Xia Y. Wu Z. Su B. Murray B. Karin M. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 3369-3381Crossref PubMed Scopus (177) Google Scholar). This observation combined with the finding that MEKK1 also regulated the JNK/SAPK pathway suggested that PAK might be the MAP4 kinase directly regulating MEKK1. We have attempted to define the relationship between PAK and control of MEKK1 function. We found that PAK1 phosphorylated MEKK1 on serine 67 of its amino-terminal regulatory domain. This residue is located within the JNK/SAPK-binding site of MEKK1. Phosphorylation of serine 67 inhibits JNK/SAPK binding to MEKK1. This site is phosphorylated in cells; its phosphorylation state is regulated. Thus, we propose a novel regulatory mechanism in which PAKs regulate the ability of MEKK1 to scaffold JNK/SAPK. 293 cells were cultured and transfected with calcium phosphate as described previously (9Xu S. We wanted to determine whether PAK1 regulates the function of MEKK1 by phosphorylation. Thus, we utilized an active, kinase domain fragment of PAK1-(232–544) and recombinant fragments of MEKK1 expressed in bacteria as substrates (Fig.1 A). In a kinase assay PAK1-(232–544) phosphorylated a fragment of MEKK1 comprising residues 30–220 (Fig. 1 B), but did not phosphorylate fragments derived from more COOH-terminal sequence. Following phosphorylation by PAK1, the mass of MEKK1 fragment residues 30–220, measured by MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry, increased by 82 Da, a mass equivalent within experimental error to the addition of a single phosphoryl group (80 Da). The fragment was digested with trypsin and V8 protease, and the peptides were subjected to MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry (Fig. 2 and data not shown). Serine 67 was identified as the phosphorylation site (Fig. 2,A–D). The location of serine 67 is notable for the fact that it occurs within the JNK/SAPK-binding domain (TableI and Fig. 5) (9Xu S. Peptide A, which spans the region of MEKK1 phosphorylated by PAK, was synthesized in both phosphorylated and unphosphorylated forms. The phosphorylated peptide A was used as antigen to generate a polyclonal antibody that recognizes this site. The anti-phosphoserine 67 pA antibody was further purified by its affinity for phosphorylated, and lack of interaction with non-phosphorylated peptide, to enhance specificity for the phosphopeptide. Following phosphorylation by PAK1, MEKK1-(30–220) was specifically recognized by immunoblotting with the pA antibody, and this signal could be blocked by a phosphorylated peptide (Fig. 3 Aand data not shown). MEKK1-(30–220) was incubated with PAK1 over a 90-min time course. The stoichiometry of serine 67 phosphorylation was greater than 0.9 mol of phosphate/mol of MEKK1-(30–220). Recombinant active PAK1 (L107F) expressed in mammalian cells also phosphorylated MEKK1 (data not shown). Kinase assays and immunoblotting with the pA antibody demonstrated that the appearance of immunoreactivity toward phosphorylated serine 67 of MEKK1 correlated with the phosphorylation of the substrate (Fig. 3 A). A similar result was noted with MEKK1-(1–482) as PAK1 substrate (Fig. 3 B). To validate further the selectivity of the pA antibody for MEKK1 phosphorylated on serine 67, we examined the effect of dephosphorylation of serine 67 on recognition of MEKK1 by anti-pA. Recombinant full-length MEKK1 purified from Sf9 cells is characteristically multiply phosphorylated and highly active. Therefore, we tested whether it is phosphorylated on residue serine 67 and if this site can be dephosphorylated by treatment with phosphoprotein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) (Fig. 3 C). MEKK1 was phosphorylated on serine 67 as revealed by its immunoreactivity with anti-pA. Treatment of MEKK1 with PP2A resulted in the loss of immunoreactivity with anti-pA, supporting the specificity of the pA antibody only for forms of MEKK1 phosphorylated on serine 67. Anin vitro kinase reaction was performed to compare the activity of other protein kinases toward MEKK1 serine 67. Protein kinase A (PKA), SAPKαI, the catalytic fragment of MEKK1, and PAK1-(232–544) were used in kinase assays with MEKK1-(1–482) as a substrate (Fig. 3 D). Immunoblotting with anti-pA indicated that only PAK1 caused significant phosphorylation of this site. The phosphorylation of MEKK1 on serine 67 in cells and the ability of stimuli to modulate this phosphorylation were examined by immunoblotting lysates of 293 cells with anti-pA. MEKK1 from cells grown in serum-containing medium was phosphorylated on serine 67 (Fig. 4 A). A 60-min treatment with either anisomycin or UV irradiation caused the dephosphorylation of serine 67 relative to the untreated control. By contrast, treatment with TNF-α, IL-1, and EGF failed to alter serine 67 phosphorylation relative to control. The dephosphorylation of serine 67 in response to UV or anisomycin treatment correlates with increased JNK/SAPK activity (Fig. 4 B). Exposure of 293 cells to anisomycin or UV caused ∼50- and 20-fold stimulations of JNK/SAPK activity, respectively, while the combination of TNF-α, IL-1, and EGF activated JNK/SAPK in these cells only 3-fold. PAK activity measured in immune complexes from cells treated with these agents increased modestly in response to all of the agents tested (Fig. 4 C), suggesting no apparent relationship between PAK activation and phosphorylation of MEKK1 on serine 67. Using peptide binding assays, we previously determined that MEKK1 binds to JNK/SAPK via a 15-residue region (9Xu S. Cobb M.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 32056-32060Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar). By sequence alignment we noted that this peptide resembles a MAP kinase docking motif termed D domain (Table I) (34Yang S.H. Yates P.R. Whitmarsh A.J. Davis R.J. Sharrocks A.D. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 710-720Crossref PubMed Scopus (234) Google Scholar, 35Sharrocks A.D. Yang S.H. Galanis A. Trends Biochem. Sci. 2000; 25: 448-453Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (389) Google Scholar). This motif is comprised of clusters of basic and hydrophobic residues. We found that the hydrophobic residues of the MAP kinase docking site in MEK1 and MEK3b were of primary importance for the interaction between MAP kinases and their substrates (36Xu B. Stippec S. Robinson F.L. Cobb M.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 26509-26515Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar, 37Chang C.I. Xu B. Akella R. Cobb M.H. Goldsmith E.J. Mol. Cell. 2002; 9: 1241-1249Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (274) Google Scholar). To support our expectation that this region of MEKK1 behaved like a D domain, we tested whether the hydrophobic residues are important in the interaction between SAPKαI and MEKK1, using an MEKK1 wild type and mutant peptide bound to Sepharose beads. Supporting this hypothesis, mutation of the two hydrophobic residues alone significantly reduced the interaction between SAPKαI and the MEKK1 D domain peptide (Fig. 5). The peptide binding assay was used to characterize the effect of phosphorylation of serine 67 on the ability of the MEKK1 D domain to bind SAPKαI. As above, peptide A bound SAPKαI significantly in this assay, if either 50 or 100 nmSAPKαI was incubated with the peptide beads (Fig.6 A and data not shown). Binding was weakly detected even at 10 nm input SAPKαI. The ability of peptide A to bind SAPKαI was comparable with SAPKαI binding to a peptide that contained the MKK4 D domain (data not shown). However, pA bound SAPKαI much less well, most likely due to the steric or charge effects of introducing a phosphate group in the middle of the D domain. To confirm that phosphorylation of serine 67 reduced the capacity of MEKK1 to bind to JNK/SAPK, we examined binding of 50 nmSAPKαI to His6-MEKK1-(1–482) in which serine 67 was either unphosphorylated or phosphorylated by PAK1 (Fig. 6 B). The SAPKαI·MEKK1 complexes were harvested by binding His6-MEKK1-(1–482) to nickel-agarose beads. Western analysis of proteins on the collected beads revealed much less SAPKαI associated with phosphorylated MEKK 1–482. This finding supports the conclusion that phosphorylation of MEKK1 by PAK1 significantly impairs JNK/SAPK binding. The relevance of serine 67 to MEKK1 function and JNK/SAPK signaling was tested by comparing the abilities of peptides A and pA coupled to Sepharose beads to bind JNK/SAPK from 293 cells untreated or exposed to UV light (Fig. 7 A). No JNK/SAPK was associated with empty beads. Both 46- and 54-kDa isoforms of JNK/SAPK were associated with peptide A beads; stimulation with UV light neither increased nor decreased JNK/SAPK binding, as reported previously (9Xu S. Cobb M.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 32056-32060Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar). In contrast, no JNK/SAPK immunoreactivity could be detected with pA beads. The activity of the JNK/SAPK associated with the peptides was tested utilizing an in vitro kinase assay with c-Jun as substrate. Consistent with the immunoblotting results, little activity was detected on pA beads, while UV-stimulated Jun phosphorylating activity was associated with A beads. To demonstrate that the interactions detected with peptides bound to beads revealed changes in interactions that occurred with full-length MEKK1, endogenous MEKK1 was immunoprecipitated, and the immunoprecipitates were probed for the presence of JNK/SAPKs (Fig.7 B). Cells were untreated or treated with the combination of TNF-α, IL-1, and EGF, conditions in which phosphorylation of MEKK1 on serine 67 was high (see Fig. 4 A), or with anisomycin or UV irradiation, conditions in which phosphorylation of MEKK1 on serine 67 was low. Relatively little of either the 54- or 46-kDa forms of JNK/SAPKs were associated with MEKK1 under the first two sets of conditions. On the other hand, significant amounts of JNK/SAPK proteins were bound to MEKK1 isolated from cells treated with anisomycin or UV, which promoted MEKK1 dephosphorylation. These findings support the conclusion that phosphorylation of serine 67 inhibits the interaction of MEKK1 with JNK/SAPK isoforms, thereby regulating the linkage between MEKK1 and the JNK/SAPK pathway. MEKK1 activity is low in untreated cells and high in cells stimulated with UV or anisomycin, conditions that promote dephosphorylation of serine 67 (13). These results suggest that phosphorylation of serine 67 does not enhance MEKK1 kinase activity. Nevertheless, we examined the effect of phosphorylation of serine 67 on MEKK1 activity in vitro. Recombinant MEKK1 was phosphorylated by PAK either without or with prior dephosphorylation with PP2A. MEKK1 not treated with PP2A had high basal activity; phosphorylation by PAK caused no change in its ability to phosphorylate the substrate kinase-dead MEK4 (Fig.7 B). However, serine 67 is significantly phosphorylated in this form of MEKK1 (Fig. 3 C). Therefore, MEKK1 was treated with PP2A, which removes phosphate from serine 67 as well as other sites (38Cobb M.H. Xu S. Cheng M. Ebert D. Robbins D. Goldsmith E. Robinson M. Adv. Pharmacol. 1996; 36: 49-65Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 39Deak J.C. Templeton D.J. Biochem. J. 1997; 322: 185-192Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar), before phosphorylation by PAK. Treatment with PP2A reduced MEKK1 activity; MEKK1 activity was increased modestly following PAK phosphorylation. D domains are commonly found in MAP kinase binding partners and substrates and are comprised of basic and hydrophobic residues (35Sharrocks A.D. Yang S.H. Galanis A. Trends Biochem. Sci. 2000; 25: 448-453Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (389) Google Scholar). D domains interact with MAP kinases via a hydrophobic binding groove that extends toward the active site from the opposite surface of the kinase and includes an acidic cluster that attracts basic residues of D domains to the groove (37Chang C.I. Xu B. Akella R. Cobb M.H. Goldsmith E.J. Mol. Cell. 2002; 9: 1241-1249Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (274) Google Scholar, 40Tanoue T. Adachi M. Moriguchi T. Nishida E. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 110-116Crossref PubMed Scopus (691) Google Scholar). The association of MEKs and substrates with MAP kinases is thought to be regulated by the phosphorylation state of the MAP kinase or the substrate in regions outside the D domain or docking groove (41Adachi M. Fukuda M. Nishida E. EMBO J. 1999; 18: 5347-5358Crossref PubMed Scopus (242) Google Scholar, 42Hsiao K.-M. Chou S. Shih S.-J. Ferrell Jr., J.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 5480-5484Crossref PubMed Scopus (97) Google Scholar). We find that phosphorylation of MEKK1 within the D domain regulates the JNK/SAPK binding capability of MEKK1. Pulido and co-workers (43Pulido R. Zuniga A. Ullrich A. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 7337-7350Crossref PubMed Scopus (272) Google Scholar, 44Blanco-Aparicio C. Torres J. Pulido R. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 147: 1129-1136Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar) reported that the tyrosine phosphatases PTP-SL and STEP were phosphorylated within a D domain, termed a kinase interaction motif, by PKA. Phosphorylation by PKA decreased the association of the phosphatases with ERK2 and p38 MAP kinase. Interestingly, we note the frequent occurrence of serine or threonine residues within D domains of MAP kinase binding partners (Table I), suggesting this is a more common mechanism than currently recognized. The regulation of MEKK1 activity has proved to be complex. Of the numerous binding partners identified, some may induce dis-inhibition of the catalytic domain or promote auto-activation. Indeed, recent work has suggested that oligomerization via Traf2 and GCK facilitates MEKK1 activation, probably by increasing its local concentration (19Chadee D.N. Yuasa T. Kyriakis J.M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2002; 22: 737-749Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). The role of phosphorylation in regulating MEKK1 function has been difficult to sort out due in large part to the fact that MEKK1 is highly phosphorylated in its active state and contains numerous potential phosphorylation sites. Recombinant MEKK1 overexpressed in mammalian cells or in Sf9 cells is highly active (33Xu S. Robbins D.J. Christerson L.B. English J.M. Vanderbilt C.A. Cobb M.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 5291-5295Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar). Treatment with phosphatase substantially reduces its activity, indicating that phosphorylation state is a significant determinant of its activity (38Cobb M.H. Xu S. Cheng M. Ebert D. Robbins D. Goldsmith E. Robinson M. Adv. Pharmacol. 1996; 36: 49-65Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). Two threonine residues that lie within the activation loop of the core MEKK1 catalytic domain have been shown to be phosphorylated and required for kinase activation (39Deak J.C. Templeton D.J. Biochem. J. 1997; 322: 185-192Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). Our in vitro experiments suggest that phosphorylation of serine 67 by PAK1 modestly increases MEKK1 activity. This is the first instance of a PAK-dependent phosphorylation that has an impact on the JNK/SAPK pathway. Nevertheless, we find this site phosphorylated in resting cells and under other conditions in which MEKK1 activity is low, and dephosphorylated under conditions in which MEKK1 is strongly activated. Thus, despite an effect on in vitro activity, our data are most consistent with the conclusion that phosphorylation of serine 67 has little to do with altering MEKK1 activity, but instead regulates its associations. What determines the phosphorylation state of MEKK1 serine 67 is not yet clear. In resting 293 cells MEKK1 is phosphorylated on serine 67. Certain stimuli, including UV irradiation and anisomycin, cause the nearly complete dephosphorylation of this site, while EGF in combination with other agents has little net effect on the phosphorylation state of this site. PAK1 activity is relatively low in resting cells and is stimulated to a small extent by the growth factors and other agents used in this study (see also Ref. 45Roig J. Traugh J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 31119-31122Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). Thus, there is no apparent correlation between serine 67 phosphorylation and total PAK1 activity in cells. The phosphorylation of this site might be controlled in a manner not reflected by total PAK1 activity, but rather by a small fraction of PAK1 that may be colocalized with MEKK1. It is also possible that other PAK isoforms or other unidentified protein kinases are the major MEKK1 serine 67 kinases. No other potential serine 67 kinases were implicated by analysis of the sequence surrounding serine 67 using the Scansite website (www.scansite.mit.edu) nor did PKA phosphorylate this site. Alternatively, the phosphorylation state of this site may be determined primarily by regulated dephosphorylation. If this is so, PAK may tonically phosphorylate serine 67, which would remain in this state until an appropriate phosphatase is targeted to MEKK1. PP2A can dephosphorylate this site. We previously found that the catalytic subunit of PP2A binds tightly to MEKK1 in vitro; however, the potential physiological significance of this interaction is unknown. 2S. Xu and M. H. Cobb, unpublished data. Perhaps the regulated association of a phosphatase such as PP2A with MEKK1 may determine the extent of phosphorylation of serine 67 at any given time. We propose a model that may account for MEKK1-mediated JNK/SAPK activation based on earlier work and the studies described here. MEKK1 can bind both to MEK4 and JNK/SAPK, forming a complex containing a three-protein kinase signaling cascade. MEK4 binds to the kinase domain of MEKK1 and apparently dissociates from MEKK1 once it is activated. JNK/SAPK binds to the D domain near the NH2 terminus of MEKK1 from approximately residues 62–70 (9Xu S. Cobb M.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 32056-32060Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar, 10Xia Y. Wu Z. Su B. Murray B. Karin M. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 3369-3381Crossref PubMed Scopus (177) Google Scholar). PAK1 can phosphorylate MEKK1 on serine 67 within its JNK/SAPK-binding D domain. Phosphorylation of MEKK1 on serine 67 alters the state of the D domain, thereby decreasing its affinity for JNK/SAPK. Under these conditions JNK/SAPK is not recruited into the MEKK1 signaling module. MEK4, unlike other MEKs in MAP kinase pathways, is known to have another substrate, the retinoid X receptor (46Lee H.Y. Suh Y. Robinson M.J. Clifford J.L. Hong W.K. Woodgett J.R. Cobb M.H. Mangelsdorf D.J. Kurie J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 32193-32199Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar). It is possible that MEK4 may preferentially phosphorylate the retinoid X receptor if JNK/SAPK is not associated with MEKK1. Upon dephosphorylation of serine 67, JNK/SAPK will reassociate with the MEKK1 D domain, allowing it to be activated when MEKK1 is activated. In this model the relative state of phosphorylation of serine 67 will control the coupling of MEKK1 to the JNK/SAPK pathway. We thank Steve Stippec for some Western analysis and for the preparation of full-length MEKK1 from Sf9 cells; Bing-e Xu for GST PAK1-(232–544) protein; Chung-I Chang, Shashi Prajapati, Michael Lawrence, Tara Beers-Gibson, Angelique Whitehurst, and Bing-e Xu for comments about the manuscript; Steve Afendis and Steve Madden for mass spectrometry analysis; Eric Brown for peptide synthesis; and Dionne Ware for administrative assistance.

Hair fiber differentiation and maturation involves the close interaction between hair keratins and their associated proteins, KAPs. Recently, a cluster of seven humanKAP multigen families has been identified on chromosome 17q12-21 among which were four hKAP1 genes (hKAP1.1B, hKAP1.3, hKAP1.4, andhKAP1.5). In addition, there were previous as well as recent reports on four additional hKAP1 genes (hKAP1.1A, hKAP1.2, hKAP1.6, andhKAP1.7) with unknown chromosomal location. In this study, we have analyzed these eight hKAP1 genes in unrelated Japanese and Caucasian individuals and discovered thathKAP1.1A, hKAP1.6, and hKAP1.7represent size polymorphisms of the hKAP1.1B gene. In addition, we show that hKAP1.2 as well as three hitherto unknown genes (hKAP1.8A, hKAP1.8B, andhKAP1.9) are size polymorphisms of the hKAP1.3gene. In contrast, no polymorphic alleles were found for thehKAP1.4 and hKAP1.5 genes. We provide evidence that the polymorphic hKAP1.1B and hKAP1.3alleles arose mainly by intragenic deletion and/or duplication events of distinct pentapeptide repeats typical for hKAP1 genes. We also demonstrate the occurrence of both frequent and rare population-specific hKAP1.1B and hKAP1.3alleles, which were obviously generated after the divergence of the Caucasian and Japanese lineage. In addition, by means of a pan-hKAP1 antibody, we confirm the previous hKAP1 family mRNA localization data in the middle to upper cortex of the human anagen hair follicle. The major structural proteins of mammalian hair are the hair keratins and their associated proteins. The hair keratins belong to the large keratin multigene family, which mainly comprises genes that are expressed in various types of epithelia. Hair keratins form the intermediate filament (IF) 1The abbreviations used are: IF, intermediate filament; KAP, hair keratin-associated protein; RT, reverse transcription; RACE, rapid amplification of cDNA ends; ISH, in situ hybridization; IIF, indirect immunofluorescence; DTT, dithiothreitol; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline.1The abbreviations used are: IF, intermediate filament; KAP, hair keratin-associated protein; RT, reverse transcription; RACE, rapid amplification of cDNA ends; ISH, in situ hybridization; IIF, indirect immunofluorescence; DTT, dithiothreitol; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline.network in trichocytes, i.e. cells that populate the central hair-forming compartment (hair matrix, cortex, and cuticle) of the anagen hair follicle. In the hair cortex, hair keratin IFs are embedded in an interfilamentous matrix, consisting of hair keratin-associated proteins (KAPs), which are essential for the formation of a rigid and resistant hair shaft through their extensive disulfide bond cross-linking with abundant cysteine residues of hair keratins (1Powell B.C. Nesci A. Rogers G.E. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1991; 642: 1-20Google Scholar,2Powell B.C. Rogers G.E. Jolles P. Zahn H. Höcker H. Formation and Structure of Human Hair. Powell B.C. J. Invest. Dermatol. 1993; 101: S50-S55Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar). This cluster contained four novel hKAP1 genes, which were designated hKAP1.1B, hKAP1.3, hKAP1.4, and hKAP1.5 (16Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Winter H. Ehmann C. Praetzel S. Schweizer J. J. Biol. On the basis of sequence differences among these genes and the previously described hB2A andhB2B genes, we renamed the latter hKAP1.1A(hB2A) and hKAP1.2 (hB2B), respectively (16Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Winter H. Ehmann C. Praetzel S. Schweizer J. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 19440-19451Google Scholar). In addition, we identified two novel KAP1 members, hKAP1.6 and hKAP1.7, by PCR amplification of genomic DNA from a Japanese individual and by screening a Caucasian scalp cDNA library (17Shimomura Y. Aoki N. Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Schweizer J. Ito M. J. Invest. Dermatol. 2002; 118: 226-231Google Scholar). However, the chromosomal assignment of the hKAP1.6 andhKAP1.7 genes as well as that of the hKAP1.1A andhKAP1.2 genes (9Zhumbaeva B.D. Gening L.V. Gazaryan K.G. Mol. Biol. 1992; 26: 550-555Google Scholar) remained to be determined.Each of the eight hKAP1 members shared a generally high homology in both nucleotide and amino acid sequence (16Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Winter H. Ehmann C. Praetzel S. Schweizer J. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 19440-19451Google Scholar, 17Shimomura Y. Aoki N. Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Schweizer J. Ito M. J. Invest. However, comparisons among the hKAP1.1A/B, hKAP1.6, andhKAP1.7 genes not only yielded a particularly high amino acid homology but also an extraordinary conservation of their 3′-noncoding region and, with the exception of the hKAP1.1Agene (9Zhumbaeva B.D. Gening L.V. Gazaryan K.G. Mol. Biol. 1992; 26: 550-555Google Scholar), their 5′-noncoding region (17Shimomura Y. Aoki N. Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Schweizer J. Ito M. J. Invest. Dermatol. 2002; 118: 226-231Google Scholar). These findings prompted us to further investigate the relationship among these genes. In this study, we analyzed genomic DNA of 100 Japanese and 100 Caucasian individuals and show that the hKAP1.1A,hKAP1.6, and hKAP1.7 genes are size polymorphisms of the hKAP1.1B gene. Moreover, a polymorphism analysis of the remaining hKAP1 genes resulted in the identification of several polymorphic variants of the hKAP1.3 gene. RT-PCR, 3′-RACE, ISH, and IIF studies were performed showing the expression of these genes in the human hair follicle.DISCUSSIONRecently, we described an ∼400-kb gene cluster on human chromosome 17q12-q21, which contained seven KAP multigene families, embedded into the type I keratin gene domain. Among these families were four genes of the hKAP1 family that we designatedhKAP1.1B, hKAP1.3, hKAP1.4, andhKAP1.5 (16Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Winter H. Ehmann C. Praetzel S. Schweizer J. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 19440-19451Google Scholar). In a subsequent paper, we identified two additional human KAP1 genes, which were termedhKAP1.6 and hKAP1.7 (17Shimomura Y. Aoki N. Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Schweizer J. Ito M. J. Invest. Dermatol. 2002; 118: 226-231Google Scholar). Together with two previously described human KAP1 genes, originally designatedhB2A and hB2B (9Zhumbaeva B.D. Gening L.V. Gazaryan K.G. Mol. Biol. 1992; 26: 550-555Google Scholar) but later renamedhKAP1.1A and hKAP1.2 by us (16Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Winter H. Ehmann C. Praetzel S. Schweizer J. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 19440-19451Google Scholar), the number of known hKAP1 genes amounted then to eight. Because thehKAP1.1A, hKAP1.2, hKAP1.6, andhKAP1.7 genes did not appear to be part of theKAP gene cluster on chromosome 17q12-21, we suggested their location elsewhere in the human genome (17Shimomura Y. Aoki N. Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Schweizer J. Ito M. J. Invest. Dermatol. 2002; 118: 226-231Google Scholar).In this study carried out in a large collection of Japanese and Caucasian individuals, we correct this assumption by demonstrating that the hKAP1.1A, hKAP1.6, and hKAP1.7genes are in fact polymorphic alleles of the hKAP1.1B gene. However, of these four polymorphic alleles, only thehKAP1.1B and hKAP1.6 alleles were found in this study. Although the hKAP1.1B allele was detected with high frequency in both populations investigated, the frequency of thehKAP1.6 allele was distinctly different in Japanese (0.210) and Caucasian individuals (0.005), thus indicating that most probablyhKAP1.6 represents a Japanese-specific polymorphism (TableII). Although the hKAP1.1A and hKAP1.7 alleles were not found in this study, each of them might represent a rare polymorphic hKAP1.1B allele.Similar to the hKAP1.1B gene, we also identified several polymorphic alleles of the hKAP1.3 gene. ThehKAP1.3 and hKAP1.8A alleles were commonly found with high frequencies in both Japanese and Caucasian individuals (TableII). In contrast, the hKAP1.8B allele was present in 40 Japanese individuals, whereas it was found in only a single Caucasian individual (Table II). Just like the hKAP1.6 allele, the frequency of the hKAP1.8B allele is so different between the two populations (0.200 in Japanese; 0.005 in Caucasians) that it can also be considered a Japanese-specific polymorphism. ThehKAP1.9 allele was identified only in a single Caucasian individual (Table II), suggesting that it represents a rarehKAP1.3 size polymorphism in the Caucasian population. ThehKAP1.8A allele and the Japanese-specifichKAP1.8B allele are identical with the exception of three nucleotide differences (G-C, C-T, and G-A, Fig. 3 A) in their coding regions. In all of the individuals analyzed, no recombination among these three sites has been observed. Thus, the nucleotides C, T, and A in hKAP1.8B appear to be single nucleotide polymorphisms typical for the Japanese population.It is evident that the two Japanese-specific hKAP1.6 andhKAP1.8B alleles arose subsequent to the divergence of the Caucasian and Japanese lineage. Interestingly, an overall analysis of the distribution of the hKAP1.1B and hKAP1.3alleles in Japanese and Caucasian individuals (TableIII) suggests that the hKAP1.6and hKAP1.8B alleles might be linked with a high frequency. Pending the confirmation of frequenthKAP1.6/hKAP1.8B linkage by genomic sequencing, this could mean that the actual distribution of thehKAP1.6/hKAP1.8B allele goes back to a founder effect in the Japanese population subsequent to the divergence from the Caucasian lineage. Conceptually, the linkage of hKAP1.6 andhKAP1.8B would also help to explain the presence of these two alleles in a single Caucasian individual by unrecognized Japanese ancestry.Table IIIRelationship between the hKAP1.1B and hKAP1.3 geneshKAP1.1B genehKAP1.3 geneJapanese (100 individuals)Caucasian (100 individuals)1.1B/1.1B1.3/1.313351.3/1.8A35401.8A/1.8A13231.8A/1.9011.1B/1.61.3/1.8B1711.8A/1.8B1801.8A/1.8A1*01.6/1.61.8B/1.8B201.8A/1.8B1*0hKAP1.6 and hKAP1.8B alleles are indicated in bold. Note that the individuals who are homozygous for thehKAP1.1B allele never have the hKAP1.8B allele, which exists only in individuals with the hKAP1.6 allele. Asterisks show individuals that do not exhibit linkage between thehKAP1.6 and hKAP1.8B alleles. Open table in a new tab We previously divided hKAP1 proteins into five distinct domains: an N-terminal domain, a highly repetitive domain I, a central non-repetitive domain, a less repetitive domain II, and a C-terminal domain (16Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Winter H. Ehmann C. Praetzel S. Schweizer J. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 19440-19451Google Scholar, 17Shimomura Y. Aoki N. Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Schweizer J. Ito M. J. Invest. Dermatol. 2002; 118: 226-231Google Scholar, 27Shimomura Y. Aoki N. Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Schweizer J. Ito M. J. Invest. Dermatol. Symp. Proc. 2002; (in press)Google Scholar) (Fig. 6). The multialignment of both hKAP1.1B and hKAP1.3 with their respective polymorphic variants revealed that the differences among them were essentially because of variations in the repetitive domain I (Fig. 6). In hKAP1.1A/B and hKAP1.3, this domain comprises two extended tandem repeats, each consisting of a previously unidentified 16-amino acid segment “FCG(F/Y)PS(C/F)STGGTC(G/D)SS” followed by 6 and 4 (4 and 4 in hKAP1.3) previously described cysteine-rich pentapeptide repeats, respectively (Fig. 6). Relative to hKAP1.1A/B, the Japanese-specific hKAP1.6 protein has entirely lost the first version of the extended quasi tandem repeats of the repetitive domain I. Based on the numerical dominance of the hKAP1.1B allele in both the Caucasian and Japanese population, we assume that the hKAP1.6 protein arose through the corresponding intragenic deletion in the hKAP1.1B gene. Moreover, a one amino acid exchange (Fig. 6 A, Pro to Arg in bold) at the beginning of the second tandem repeat of domain I of the two proteins resulted also from an accompanying single nucleotide polymorphism (CCT to CGT) in the two genes. Compared with hKAP1.3, the hKAP1.8 protein exhibits an insertion of two tandem pentapeptide repeats in the repetitive domain I (Fig. 6 B). Because hKAP1.3and hKAP1.8A exhibit nearly identical allele frequencies (Table II), it is difficult to decide whether this difference is originally attributed to a corresponding intragenic insertion inhKAP1.3 or a deletion in hKAP1.8A. Although the generation of hKAP1.9 can also be traced back to an intragenic deletion of repetitive segments in domain I of either the hKAP1.3 orhKAP1.8A gene (Fig. 6 B), notable exceptions from this rule exist for the evolution of the hKAP1.2 and hKAP1.7 proteins. Although relative to hKAP1.3, hKAP1.2 still exhibits the loss of two tandem pentapeptide repeats of the repetitive domain I. It also differs from all known hKAP1 proteins by the unique sequence FCDFLASQLVDLQLS, replacing the second 16 amino acid repeat FCG(F/Y)PS(C/F)STGGTC(G/D)SS of the repetitive domain I as well as by an aberrant SSCHS C-terminal sequence (Fig. 6 B). Considering that the hKAP1.2gene is physically linked with the polymorphic hKAP1.1Bvariant hKAP1.1A, which also exhibits unique sequences in its 5′-upstream region (9Zhumbaeva B.D. Gening L.V. Gazaryan K.G. Mol. Biol. 1992; 26: 550-555Google Scholar), it is clear that these genes have evolved together and may represent rare possibly geographical polymorphisms. This may also be true for the hKAP1.7 gene, which relative to hKAP1.1A exhibits a highly unusual deletion starting within the FCG(F/Y)PS(C/F)STGGTC(G/D)SS segment of domain I and terminating in the central non-repetitive domain (Fig.6 A).It should be emphasized that the main type of size polymorphisms described here for the hKAP1.1B and hKAP1.3 genes has previously been reported for sheep KAP1 genes. At present, four sheep KAP1 genes, B2A throughB2D, are known (32Rogers G.R. Hickford J.G. Bickerstaffe R. Anim. Genet. 1994; 25: 407-415Google Scholar). Because of species-specific amino acid insertions, their orthology with the four human KAP1 genes,hKAP1.1B, hKAP1.3, hKAP1.4 andhKAP1.5, is difficult to assess (16Rogers M.A. Langbein L. Winter H. Ehmann C. Praetzel S. Schweizer J. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 19440-19451Google Scholar). Remarkably, however, the analysis of the sheep genes in unrelated animals of the same breeding revealed both insertion or deletion polymorphisms of the cysteine-rich pentapeptide tandem-repeats in the repetitive domain I of two proteins, B2A and B2C, but not in the remaining B2B and B2D proteins (32Rogers G.R. Hickford J.G. Bickerstaffe R. Anim. Genet. 1994; 25: 407-415Google Scholar). Thus, the present data in two species clearly indicate a functional tolerance of a varying number of cysteine-rich repeats in distinct KAP1 members.Tolerance of extended frequently population-specific tandem-repeat pattern polymorphisms, have also been reported for both the human and animal loricrin and involucrin genes (33Simon M. Phillips M. Green H. Stroh H. Glatt K. Bruns G. Latt S.A. Am. J. Hum. Genet. 1989; 45: 910-916Google Scholar, 34Simon M. Phillips M. Green H. Genomics. 1991; 9: 576-580Google Scholar, 35Yoneda K. Genet. 1993; 53: 279-286Google Scholar, 37Djian P. Delhomme B. Green H. Am. J. Hum. Genet. 1995; 56: 1367-1372Google Scholar). On the other hand, it has been shown that heterozygous point mutations, which entail a frameshift in the loricrin gene leading to abnormal protein synthesis, are causal for the ichthyotic variant of Vohwinkel's syndrome (38Maestrini E. Monaco A.P. McGrath J.A. Ishida-Yamamoto A. Camisa C. Hovnanian A. Weeks D.E. Lathrop M. Uitto J. Christiano A.M. Nat. Genet. 1996; 13: 70-77Google Scholar, 39Korge B.P. Ishida-Yamamoto A. Punter C. Dopping-Hepenstal P.J.C. Iizuka H. Stephenson A. Eady R.A.J. Munro C.S. J. Invest. Dermatol. 1997; 109: 604-610Google Scholar, 40Armstrong D.K.B. McKenna K.E. Hughes A.E. J. Invest. Dermatol. 1998; 111: 702-704Google Scholar). In this study, we also detected a heterozygous point mutation that would lead to a heavily truncated hKAP1.1B protein in two individuals of a two-generation Japanese family. Although one of these individuals suffered from a rather severe hair disorder resembling hypothrichosis, her father had apparently normal hair, thus questioning a causality of the mutation in the affected individual. However, it is known that a variety of hair disorders, i.e. monilethrix or the loose anagen hair syndrome, can considerably improve with age (41Zimmermann R. Dermatol. Monatsschr. 1983; 169: 638-645Google Scholar,42Li V.W. Baden H. Kvedar J.C. Dermatol. Clin. 1996; 14: 745-751Google Scholar), particularly in those cases where the childhood phenotype was only recognizable by electron microscopy (43Winter H. Labrèze C. Chapalain V. Surlève-Bazeille J.E. Mercier M. Rogers M.A. Taieb A. Schweizer J. J. Invest. Dermatol. 1998; 111: 169-172Google Scholar). Although theoretically this may also be the case in the Japanese family we analyzed, it is clear that further studies on larger affected families, which also would allow linkage analyses or alternatively transgenic models, are needed to confirm the pathogenicity of single mutated KAP members.In conclusion, our study has revealed tandem-repeat pattern polymorphisms in human KAP1 genes. Obviously, despite the concomitant loss of a large number of cysteine residues, which should influence the strength of KAP protein interaction with hair keratin IFs, this phenomenon remains without recognizable phenotypic consequences, although structural microheterogeneities cannot be excluded. We also detected population-specific hKAP1 polymorphisms in Caucasian and Japanese individuals, which however cannot account for the differences in the respective hair phenotypes. On the other hand, it cannot be excluded that in view of the extraordinary high number of similarly repetitive KAPs potentially prone to size polymorphisms, distinct patterns of multiple KAP polymorphisms may influence the structure of the hair in a population-specific manner. Moreover, the extension of this study to other human populations, in particular from Africa and elsewhere in Asia, as well as the inclusion of our closest primate relatives may reveal KAPs to be useful tools regarding the elucidation of the time and geography of evolution of modern human populations. The major structural proteins of mammalian hair are the hair keratins and their associated proteins. The hair keratins belong to the large keratin multigene family, which mainly comprises genes that are expressed in various types of epithelia. Hair keratins form the intermediate filament (IF) 1The abbreviations used are: IF, intermediate filament; KAP, hair keratin-associated protein; RT, reverse transcription; RACE, rapid amplification of cDNA ends; ISH, in situ hybridization; IIF, indirect immunofluorescence; DTT, dithiothreitol; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline.1The abbreviations used are: IF, intermediate filament; KAP, hair keratin-associated protein; RT, reverse transcription; RACE, rapid amplification of cDNA ends; ISH, in situ hybridization; IIF, indirect immunofluorescence; DTT, dithiothreitol; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline.network in trichocytes, i.e. cells that populate the central hair-forming compartment (hair matrix, cortex, and cuticle) of the anagen hair follicle. In the hair cortex, hair keratin IFs are embedded in an interfilamentous matrix, consisting of hair keratin-associated proteins (KAPs), which are essential for the formation of a rigid and resistant hair shaft through their extensive disulfide bond cross-linking with abundant cysteine residues of hair keratins (1Powell B.C. Nesci A. Rogers G.E. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1991; 642: 1-20Google Scholar,2Powell B.C. Rogers G.E. Jolles P. Zahn H. Höcker H. Formation and Structure of Human Hair. Birkhäuser Verlag, Basel, Switzerland1997: 59-148Google Scholar). Powell B.C. J. Invest. Dermatol. 1993; 101: S50-S55Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar). Since then, the number of new KAPs from sheep, rabbit, mouse, and humans have steadily increased (2Powell B.C. Rogers G.E. Jolles P. Zahn H. Höcker H. Formation and Structure of Human Hair.
